IfTdoJph A Iff, auditor for Saifc Lake

Ho had been talking to somo friends

and fell, bruising bin face slightly on

summoned tho police niubulnnco and

had not regained eonsciougnoss at a
late hour laat night, but was reported

first taken to the hospital. Dr. S. G.
Paul is attending him. ,
Mr. A.10T is an old. resident or Salt,
hake. City and has boon prominent, hero
for years. He is a member of the
Grand Army of the .Republic and was
elect ed city auditor on tho American
party ticket.

MAKES SEVERAL OTHER
'SPEECHES DURING DAY
At Erie, Pa., the President
Outlines Plan of Compro
mise on the Arbitra
tion Treaties.
By Associated Prcs.
EHIE, Sept. J President Taft
ouded' the first of his forty-six
days of speech-making with au
address in. tho Auditorium hero
tonight. Before arriving be bad spent
nine hours in Syracuse.. N. Y., where he
made three speeches.
Tho president said he had determined
that his average during this trip would
bo four and a half speeches a day, so
he did not start out at lop speed.
Mr. Taft reserved his most import
ant uttcrunco of the day for the speech
here when he outlined a plan by which
ho hopes to wipe out objections in tho
United States senate to tho recently
negotiated treaties of arbitration with
Great Britain and France.
These treaties have been bold up and
threatened with defeat, largely because
several senators have contended that
the proposed joint high commission
which would determine whether or not
a question should bo scut to arbitra
tion practically robbed tho sonato oi
its function of passing upon the ques
tion. Suggests Compromise.
The president tonight suggested as a
compromise 'tbtrtlTlii? American "members
of Hiich a joint; commission should bo
confirmed by tho senate. He said he
saw no reason why they should not be,
if congress, or tho. senate, thought it
dangerous to trust tlio president only
to make the appointmeiita.
Mr. Taft indicated that he would go
further than this and be willing to
wipe out the joint " high commission
entirety, if need be, and loave.the de
cision as to whothcr a question is ar
bitral to a board of arbitration. Ho
also would be willing to havo this board
pass not only upon the merits of tho
question, bur. upon tho jurisdiction.
"Either wo arc in favor of arbitra
tion on issues which are likely to load
ijo war, or we aro not,'' ho exclaimed.
"Jf we aro in. favor of war as the
only means of settling questions of im
portance betwoen countries, then lot us
recognize it as a principle, and decline
all arbitration:, but if wo are really in
favor of arbitration as a- means of
avoiding war, then why should wc not
be willing to submit to impartial men
tho decision upon a question mthor
than to lenvo it to the result of a
bloody battle, in which, with a fair
cause, we may be beaten or with an
unjust cause wo may conquer?"
Biding His Time.
The president did not plunge direct
ly into a defonso of his administra
tion, as some of his hearers had ex
pected. One of tho most significant
things he said was at tho luncheon
with tho New York state fair commis
sioners at Syracuse, when ho explained
why he had not discussed reciprocity
in his outdoor address to several thou
sands of city folk and farmors.
"I-am not going to speak about reci
procity," he said, "until nfter the
matter is settled in Canada. We have
done "our part and we aro waiting, and
it is just as well for us to keep quiet."
Mr. Taft also explained in Syracuse
why he happened to decide upon this
13,000-mile jaunt to the Pacific and
through "tho enemy's countr.y" of in
surgency. This trip was just like
"Tonsy," ho said; "it .ist growod."
"Two years ago T promised Gover
nor Hughes to visit your state fnir.
Then I made an appointment with Con
crrcBsman Madison of Kansas to visit
Kansas and Hutchinson on tho semi
centennial of the state.
"These two engagement were the
reason of my downfall. Thereafter an
engagement in San Prnncisco accom
plished by completo .ruin. Now 1 have
before mo forty days of travel and T
do not know how many speeches, and
I ask your prayers Tor my survival."
Explains His Trip.
In further explanation of his trip, the
president said:'
'T expect to talk on this trip about
tho issues of the dav. and somo of my
policies if I may dignify my relation
to them by the noiSPssive case and
count them among tho issues of the
day. I hope I may he able tu bring i
somewhat more clearly from Uie stand
point of one who is charged with some
responsibility in respect of them, many
of the questions that perplex the legis
lators and executive at Washington."'
At the state fair grounds in l-yra-ciieo
the president found himself in tho
midst of one of the groa test crowds ever
gathered there, and estimated by somo
as in the neighborhood of 100,000. Ho
sharod honors with an aeroplanist who
was constantly' bu..ing over the heads
of the people, and several of the most
noted automobile rnoers in tho country.
Continued on Pago Three.

y Associated-' Press.

M& OF BELGIUM
CM1 TO AMERICA

NEW YOUK, Sopl. ICKing Al
bert's dream oi endowing Belgium with

merce., industry and mineral wealth,

near future. It is one of the few pro
jects of Leopold IT. with which his
uophew 'and successor has had any
sympathy. Albert began fo interest
himself about the question before he
attained his majority.
Iu 1S10S he spent several weeks in
visiting the seaports, shipping Centers,
shipyards, etc., of .Europe. Uis visit

to maritime questions. Jt, was ns a
.journalist who mudo a stud- of ques

is known he is the only newspaper re
porter who has ever become a king, and
whon he visits the United States de
serves, as such, to be made an honorary
member of every Amcricau press club.

expects to devote at least a couple of
weeks to the examination of the Pan
nma canal work and, later on. perhaps
in tho following year.; hopes to extend
his investigations to 'the Atlantic sea
ports of South Americn.

NEW YORK. Sept. 1C lisn Dorothy

On her homeward journey Jliss Sned
cker had to make the trip alone, The

war, left. j
When she wax awakened In the morn
ing Jnst before the train arrived In Chi
cago, much to her surprise and embar
rassment she discovered the I heft. Thero

lapsed. Tho engine, rear planes and
rudder escaped damage.

sume his trip and tho motor had to be

AVafd Hew ninety-nine miles today

MRS, FOWLER IS CONFIDENT.
Mother of Transcontinental Flyer Not
Afraid He Will Be Killed.

LOS ANGELES. CaL. Sept. 1fi. "My
boy's golnj: to win. r admire hly nervo.
He Is a born blrdman. I will not worry
at all over his flight through Bpaco from
the Pacific to the Atlantic coasl. Why.
I am so happy over his grit that 1 am ac
companying the special train across the
continent that Is following him."
This tersely shows the grit of Mrs.
Robert Fowler, mother of Hob Fowler, the
California aviator who is flying a biplane
for a ?50.00O prize.
Mrs. Fowler., a middle-aged, mothorlv
woman, full of American grit and keen
tor progression, is truly proud of her hoy.
She is confident that ho will win and re
calls incidents that have happened during
his life to show "he was the one. destined
to make a successful- cross-country flight

The hlg, blue-eyed chap loves his

the decision he has made. Each time the
motherly fucc or the. California widow
has looked straight into tho manlv face

"Xo. Robert. You arc sensible. You

dence In you. Mother will not worrv.

"When Bob was a. youngster." his

but neither Robert nor I believe such

hold good because It Is only In matters
wher road or air conditions are con
cerned that mv hoy's mind Is so acute."

at Gilroy. Cal. He Is a graduate of Lc
land Stanford university. Ho has been

including Bob Burtnau. who had a nar
row escape from serious injury when

anda where the president sat. Burman

In his speech' at the fair grounds the
president spoke of the science of farm
ing. "The farmer," ho said, "is becom
ing more and more independent;, and
we have got to recognize it. T am not
0110 of those who acree altogether with
some of the alarmist addresses that, my
friend .7im Hill of the Great Northern
emits at times, in which he says we
will be starved in the course of fifty
3'ears.
"Certain it is that statistics arc
enough to put us cm guard to the ne
cessity of developing all our energies
to making the ground produce doublo
What it produces uow. They do it
abroad and there is no reason why we
should not dtx so here."
The president said. In partt
"We arc spending $15,000,000 a year
in tho maintenance of a department
of agriculture and w might as well
face the truth and realize that this
expense. Instead of decreasing. Is
hound to Increase. I hnve given much
attention to tho matter of economy
and efficiency in government. While
I do not mean to say that the present
department of agriculture, in the work
which it Is doing, might not be mado
to do tho same work for less money
by a. closer-knit organization and
greater care in expenditures. T am
confident from locking Into tho fu
ture of the department and from the
present need for expansion of Its
work that an Increase In the appro
priations each year for that depart
ment may be, and ought to he, ex
pected In the interest of the govern
ment. "The amount of information which
the farmers have received and acted
upon In their farming business from
the bureau of plant industry, from tho
bureau of soil and from the bureau
of animal Industry, In tho department
of agriculture, can hardly he orer
stated, and the dependence of tho
welfare, of the country . on the con
tinued spread of this information for
the Improvement of agriculture ought
to he emphasized whenever oppor
tunity arises.
Area of Farm Lands.
"We havo today in this country, In
continental United States, about
000,000,000 acres of land; of this. S73.
000.000 acres arc Included in the acro
age of farms. In the last ten years
that acreage did not increoso more
than 35.00,000. or a little over 4 per
cent. In lhat same time our popula
tion Increased 20 per cent. Of tho
873,000,000 acres, 177.000.000 are Im
proved farm lands. The 87.1,000.000
acres include woodland and unim
proved land. The Improved land in
farms has Increased about fi3,000.000
nrres In ten years, or some IS per
rent, hut this, it will ho seen. Is not
equal to the increase tn population.
"Now. If our population Increases
as rapidly aa it has heretofore, we
shall. In fifty years, have upward of
200.000,000 people in this country to
support, on this S7S.000.000 acrca, much
of which ls probably not capahlc of
producing a great deal. There are
some SO.OOO.OQO acres of swamp land
that can he drained and there are
2i5,O0O,000 acres of land that can be
Irrigated; hut. with at' 'hose. It Is
perfectly palpable, mat within the life
of many who are horn now wo snail
bo pressing tho limit of our self-supporting
soil unless some other method
than by the mero extension of area
he found for the Increasing of our
crop production.
New Methods Needed.
"In the next 100 vears. if this Is
to be a self-sustaining country, we
must adopt new methods of farming
and pursue them with eagerness and
Intelligent enterprise. There has been,
ns wo know, n movement from tho
farm to the city. How can these
present evils that threaten the prog
ress of our agriculture ho remedied?
How can tho movement from tho
farm to the qlty be stopped? Uow
can proper labor be securod upon the
farm? la thero no remedy, or must
we change our nature, as a people and
become a purely manufacturing na
tion and look for our future, supplies
to some other source In distant coun
tries which themselves are looking
forward to a limit on their produc
tion? "I am an optimist and believe that
situations, however threatening or
immediately discouraging, havo In
themselves elements that Justify hope
of betterment. The Increased price
of farm products has Increased tho
value of the farms and has made
more certain the profit of farming.
That necessarily works upon the cu
pidity of those who In tho past have
gone Into the city, because it offers
a prospect of a better Income and a
more, comfortable living. Today, with
Improved roads, with suburban rail
ways, with the telephone, with a
rural free delivery, and. I hope, soon
with the parcels post, the life of the
farmer will approximate much more
nearly that of his brother than It ever
has In the past.
' In addition to all these elements
that are working to the restoration
lo the farmers of Increased efficiency
In the management Is the education
that Is being tlven In the countrv
and on and near the farm In scien
tific agriculture. In' the states we
have long had agricultural colleges.
Xow these are holng suDnlcmenled
hv agricultural high schools and by
what arc called the consolidated rural
schools, all of which have the effect
to create much more than hereto
fore a closer farming communltv and
to give growing oulh a knowledge
of the best methods of agriculture
and u prospect In the high prices of
farm products of an adequate re
turn for modern farming on proper
urlnelnles.
"This will glvo to the brothers who
stay on the farm a much more cor- J
tain proGpecl of a good income and
a comfortable living than those who
seek to go In professions or to en
gage In business In which the chances
for the profltB and a comfortable liveli
hood for the Individual aro growing
lfs.s. while those upon the farms arc
rapidly Increasing. The promotion of
this movement of vocational educa
tion of the embryo farmer in the sons
of ihe present farmer ls as hlch a
function ns any government depart
ment could perform, and that Is what
Is being pnv..MOd forward under the
secretary of agriculture In every stale

David Steen Shot Down Near

Under Arrest.
By Associated Press.
PITTSBURG, Sept. 16. While driv
ing to the mines of the Superior Coal
company near here toda' with the semi
monthly pay for the minors, David
Stecn vraa ssot and instantly killed bv
highwaymen. JTis father, William 5.
Steen, who was in the buggy with him,
caught the body of his son aa it top
pled over aud emptied his rovolvod at
the fleeing bandits. The money, 3,
100, was saved.
Quadraia Orrigliel, an Jndiau. was
arrested, suspected of knowing some
thing of the crime, and it was with
difficulty that state constabulary troops
prevented tho elder Steen from throt
tling him. A man supposed to be the
other bandit was also arrested.
The shooting occurred almost, within
a stone's throw of the Stoen resi
dence, near Woodvillo. Father and son
were driving along the road when two
men appeared, and, without warning,
opened fire, 0110 with a revolver and
the other with a shotgun. Both shots
were directed at. David Steen, who
was driving, and both took effect. One
shot tore away the right hand, cutting
the reins, and the other buried itself
in his body, near the heart. When
the elder Steen shot at the bandits
they did 110I return the fire, but ran
toward the hills,
Lute in the afternoon a posse cap
tured two men answering tho general
description given by Steen,
A crowd soon gathered and the of
ficers were compelled to draw their re
volvers to keep them away while they
hurried tho suspects to the Cavucgie
jail.

South Is Growing Wealthy.
Richard II. Edwards, editor of tho Man
ufacturers' Record, who was in the city
recently, says:
"The business situation in the south
is probably better than irl any other part
of the country. Ten years of greater ag
ricultural prosperity than that section
had known since 1S00 1ms enabled farm
ers to pay off hundreds of millions of In
debtedness, to improve their lands, to
give more attention to intensive cultiva
tion, to increase the amount of fertilizers
used from ?2,000,000 in 1900 to $74,700,000
In 1910. ajid to apond vast sums in build
ing new homes. In ten years the value
of farm buildings in the sixteen southern
states increased SSOO.000,000,
Last year's cotion crop, seed included,
was worth ?9G3,000.000, Though this year
promises to be much larger, it may noc
yield such an enormous money value to
the producers, but this difference will be
partly counter-balanced by Improve
ments which will come to cotton mills,
cottonseed oil mills and other interests
through a larger supply of raw material.
Though southern farm lands more than
doubled In value between 1900 and 1910,
the average value per acre Is only one
half as much as for the whole country,
notwithstanding the fact that the south's
leading crops yield a much greater value
per acre than the wheat and corn of the
west. Last years cotion crop, for in
stance, yielded over $30 per acre, while
tho average value of wheat and corn per
acre for the country was less than one
half of that figure.
Western and eastern capitalists are in
vesting heavily in southern properties, es
pecially large tracts of hind for coloniza
tion purposes and overllowed lands for
drainage. Several million acres of wet
lunds are now being drained In Florida,
Louisiana. Texas and other states. These
lands, when redralned, yield enormous
crops. The largest seed corn growing
firm in the United States bought 15.000
acres of these lands In Louisiana and Is
now draining, preparing to grow seed
corn there.
Activity in Eailway Building.
According to census returns, the steam
and electric railroads of the United
Stales purchased 1 18,231,000 crosstics
during the calendar year 1910, paying
therefor, at point of purchase, $75,589,000,

These percentages indicate that the year
1910 was one of the greatest years of ac
tivity In railroad projection and construc
tion, Of the totaTpurchases of crosstics
during 1910, 139,590,000. or 91.2 per cent,
were made by steam railroads, while
electric, railroads purchased S.G35.000, or
5.8 per cent. Tho steady Increase In tho
number of crosstics reported as pur

255,000, as against 1C.-IC7.000 In 190S, 7,
431.000 In 190S. by 199.5 per cent, and
neujrly equaling that for 1907. the largest
over recorded. Largely as a logical re
sult -of the greater demand fro crosstics
during 1910 tho average cost per tie at
point of purchase advanced to 51 cents,
the same figure reached in 1907, as com
pared with -19 cents In 1909 and 50 cents
in 1908.

lates His Experiences as

BRITONS LIVE BY RULE
Any Departure From Ances--tral
Methods Marks One
as Being-- "Eccentric."
On his thirteenth day of employment
by tho Chicago Tribune, tho Marquis
of Queensberry, who writes sporting
stories for tho Salt Lake- Tribune, gave
tho following account o his experi
ences: BY THE MARQUIS OF QUEENS
BERRY. (Copyright, .1911, by the Marquis ol'
Queensberry.)
CHICAGO, Sept. 3b'. This is my
thirteenth day of journalism thirteen
is my lucky number, and for the bene
lit of other possible literary cubs, I
want to givo my experiences. Besides,
tho moro cubs that come along the less
of a cul) shall I bo mysolf, and tho ex
periences I have to rolato aro so pleas
ant that I sun suro many will want to
emulate mo und embrace journalism us
a profession.
1 am afraid X must apologizo lor my
age, 43. It is rather lato to start at
anything, but, strangely onough, my
father always said I -was a late colt,
who would not come till late in life.
Anyway, up to now I have always beon
a listener, and having had a life of
one continuous round, of travel and ad
venture, possibly some of The Tribtino
readers will benefit as I have by what
I have learned in tho highways and by
ways of life and develop somo of the
mild philosophy which has enabled me
to bear a life of much sorrow and many
vicissitudes of fortune with a smiling
face and without losing my hair.
Americans Are Tolerant.
Tho thing that strikes me most in
America is the general tolerant spirit
of everyone; no one seems to be preju
diced in any way, religious or social,
and all men seem to bo listened to with
an open mind and given a fair chauco
in the open field,
J have felt a thrill which I have nev
er felt before, this being absolutely my
first start in journalism, and that is the
thrill that appreciation gives, especial
ly as my boss has smiled on mc and
told me to go on and do better.
Another thing which strikes mo for
cibly hero is the youth of the men con
nected with the press giving it all the
young, vigorous ideas, nnd it is most
refreshing. In 1113" country you have to
be an old man, wear chin whiskers, and
it used even to be necessary to wear
a stovepipe hat, before you could get
anyone to listen to you.
This also applies to all the business
men I have met here; the young idea
seems to predominate, and I am wound
to say I think it is quite right. I
have often tried to force that, argu
ment' at home, but the older men hold .
the fort there and won't admit it; but
it is bound to come, aud until it docs
the old world will lose many of its
brighter spirits, who enn't stand the
heart breaking rebuffs that all origi
nality meets.
Britons Live By Rule.
They are very fond of tho word ec
centric at home, and anv one who does
not conform in every way to their an
cient Roman customs, which aro tradi
tions in public schools, passed on to
tho universities, and accepted all
through life as the standardized model,
has a rough time of it, from the sim
ple taboo to complete social ostracism.
The result is that many of our bright
est, most foarless, and original men are
not appreciated till after their death,
and then everyone cries out, "How was
it we never knew him?" But here
it seems to mo that the man gets his
merits during life, and what wo dub
eccentricity is here rather looked for
than squelched. i I always think for in
stance and this point is a hobby of
mine that no man should bo a judge
after the age of 55, as how cau a man
as old as some of the judges arc in the
Old World SO oven, and over for
one moment uuderstand the trials and
temptations of n young man, three gen
erations younger'
My arguments are borne out in his-

Harrasworths Imitate Americans.
As regards our press in Britain. 1
think the Harnisworths, proprietors of
the London Daily Mail, were the first
to copy America and give the young
till cut. a chance. The result is, an en
tirely new form of journalism, much
criticized by the older generations, but.
now generally admitted to be infinitely
more bright and breezy than the old
conservative idea.
The American interviewer strikes mc
as brilliant. T had an instance in Now
York, where a finite young man had a
good half hour s close talk with mc,
and straight away, without ever hav
ing taken a note, produced practically
verbatim what. T. had said. and. more
still, what. T had meant, Interviewing
is nil art little cultivated iu Britain,
though certainly on the increase. As
suredlj' biographical sketches and per
sonal reminiscences are bound to be in-j
tcresting, for they are so human, and
enable ono to got. an insight into what
that other half of the world is doing.
Your newspapers ou the whole are
much more personal than ours, as bar
society news and political personalities
there 'is vcrv little of the human touch
and 1 find your papers most interesting
and amusing.
As for my colleagues. I cannot say
how kind thev have been to me. Cub
as I' am, they have taken me as one
of themselves, and so far no one has
over laughed at me, for 1 fully believe
tho antics of a to-year-old cub must
raise a smile sometimes.
Anyway. I feel quite at home in Chi
cago. T tnav even sav that since T left
England 1 'fool as if T had died and
beon born again aud woke up in a new
world w'rt.h the ball at my feel., and
there 1 hopo to keep it until I have
landed a goal and won mv colors,, which
is the respect and confidence of the
public and my brother .-journalists.

. Tho atlompt to sell these views is

THE GOVERNORS ADJOURN.
It is a little laughable to read that
the Governors in annual convention at
Spring Lake, New .lerscy, all at once
found that they had nothing to do. aud
so adjourned. It is astonishing that tho
most ol them did not understand from
the first, that they had nothing to do,
and that there was nothing for them to
do. First of all, only one, in tho whole
lot was authorized by his State to act.
for it in arij' capacity what over. All
tho others were thcro merely on their
title of governor, without any author
ity lo do or to say anything, or in any
way to represent their States. Prac
tically nothing was done, aud of the
chief thing which was taken up for al
leged action hardly anything can be ex
pected to come. Wo refer huro to the
provisional action taken in regard to
the conflict on railroad rates in the
Minnesota case, involving tho general
question of the supremacy of the Fed
eral authority in interstate commerce
when it conflicts with the Stato author
ity in a given case. The governors
declared themselves in favor of mak
ing a fight for the State authority; but
thoy are in no position lo make a fight,
being in no sehbc a party to tho case,
and it being practically impossible for
them lo get into it. Aud even if they
could get in. the prospect of success
seems hopeless, since on all such ques
tions Ihc tendency of the times unit t'so
decisions of the courts are uniformly in
favor of tho Federal jurisdiction. So
strongly is this manifested generally,
Unit tho railroads thcmse.lves arc rapid
ly coming to the conclusion that the
best thing they can do is to submit
themselves entirely to Federal jurisdic
tion in their interstate commcrco busi
ness; and a number of them aro ac
tively socking Federal incorporation,
though Congress has as yet provided no
means for granting it.
But it h rather laughable, after all,
to see the suddenness with which 'the
governors woke un to the fact that they
had nothing to do, and that, in effect,
their convention was a mere assump
tion with nothing -substantial to it. :uid.
I its members with no authority, to do
I anything at all.
THAT PARTISAN JOBBERY.
When Lr. Job P. Lyon was defeated
by "tho gang'' for ronomination for
county nliornc- of this county last
year, for opposing jobbery and graft,
it was a foregone conclusion that
tho suit to recover from the Smoot or
gan, for its gTaft on Ihc publication of
tho delinquent tax list would fail. It
has failed,' this by reason of th6 omis
sion from tho plendi'ugs of the very
things that should havo been included
therein, and the absence of which tho
court notes inits decision. With these
included, as they could and should havo
boon, it can fairly bo assumed I hat. tho
court would havo come to a different
conclusion.
The case is a very plain ne, Tho
Smoot organ charged aud. collected
$5727..j0 for the publication of that list,
an amount which was considerably moro
than double tho amount which tho
treasury could collect and reimburse its
funds with on the same advertising ac
count. Undoubtedly the proper inter
pretation of tho law would limit tho
malvlinum 'charge for advertising to the
amount that the treasury could recover
from . tho delinquents, which is 25 cents
por description; but tho Smoot organ
charged - per inch, and so made tho
amount moro than double what it ought
lo havo been. Besides this, the invi
tation for bids as required by law was
not publicly made; tho wholo matter
was a partisan job put through without
die and lawful notice, aud without
compliance with the stntutcs. This is
admitted; but since tho pleadings were
not made perfect, tho court holds, while
the fact could easily have been shown
otherwise, that thoro was no collusiou
shown, and that all concerned acted in
good faith; which they certainly did
not do.
Tho fact that the, basis upon which
this transaction was put through has
been abandoned since, and was never
thought of before, never considered as
possible under tho law, is proof that
nil concerned know they were conduct
ing this matter illegally. The practical
result of it was. that the property own
ers who paid their taxes were called
upon lo pay, and did pay, more than
half of tho ajiionnt paid for advertis
ing of delinquent taxes, this being
something directly opposed to the plaiu
intent of the law, and to commou hon
esty; for when a property owner pays
his taxes, it is a clear imposition upon
him lo ask him to pay for the publica
tion of other taxpayers' delinquencies.
When a propcrt' owucr pays his taxes,
that ought to be, and iu contemplation
of the law is, his full quittance for the
year. Bui the transaction put through
collusivclj' by the commissioners with
tho Smoot organ compelled the taxpay
ers who were not. delinquent to pay for
those who were. The county treasurer,
in place of being able lo collect from
thoso delinquent in their tax the amount
of .fCi727.uO which was paid for adver
tising, was able to collocl only about
$2300 under tho law, at 25 cents per
description. The remainder had to bo
paid by those who wore not. delinquent,
aud upon whom this collect ion was a
fraud and outrage.
The cas was lost simply because it
was not earnestly prosecuted or prop
erly handled. That is the plain fact
about it, and the taxpayers in this
county were robbed of the amount
stated, by tho collusive jobbery be
tween tho county commissioners and j
the Smoot organ. It was a predatory
raid upon the county treasury, impu
dent, hra7.cn, and lawless- It is uot in
the least likely that any such a raid
was ever attempted before in an- coun
ty in the United States, and it is not
likely to bo repeated even here. The
basis upon which it was manipulated
was so clearly outside of tho law, aud
so manifestly a robbery of the taxpay
ers who had paid, that, even the job
bers themselves did not have the hardi
hood lo proceed ou that basis the next
year.
EXTENT OF SUFFRAGE.
We. arc asked to give our opinion on
tho following question as stated:
Suit Lake City. Sept. 13.
Editor Trlbuno: Will you kindly Ivc
your opinion upon the following-.
A claims thut In Staten where, woman
suffrage Is allowed fenmles have an ceiual
right with males to votu for all State und
municipal ofiicpnt. :ilso Tor Representa
tives to Ihc United States Congress; but
not the right to vote for Presidential
Electors, bceause the Constitution of Ihc
United States does not mention remain
votPii? In connection with the manner of
conduct In a Presidential olnellim.
He further argues that It Is an unfair
advantage for four or live State, with
woman suffrage, to be In a position to
possibly change the result of a close Na
tional election, which would have boon
otherwise with the femalo vote elim
inated, and where mioh a contlgemy
should arise he contends It would he
good grounds for contest.
On "tho other sddc, H contends that
inasmuch as tho women are entitled to
voto for Congressional Representative?,
nnd tho50 officials go to Washington and
assist In making the general laws that
govern our country, there can be no doubt
about the National recognition of the. le
gality of the women votes for Presiden
tial Electors.
How doc:i It look to you? R.
To which our reply is. that B is cor
rect so far as the practical fact, is con
cerned. The woman vote in the;womcu
suffrage Stales on Presidential electors
just as they do on Representatives in
Congress, and on State, county, and
municipal officers. When A holds that
tho constitution of tho United Slates
governs, ho is wrong so far as fixing
an' qualifieaf ions for sttffragc is con
cerned. There is no such thing as na
tional suffrage; tho States regulate the
suffrage to suit themselves. Nor docs
it follow, as' A seems to think, that
it makes a difference in deciding a
Presidential election whether tho wo
men voto or not. It is no injustice to
any of the other States to have tho
women vote for President; because tho
State has just so manv (doctors, and tho
women's vote does not inereaso this
muubcr at all. Ffah, for instance, in
the electoral college has had thrco
voles. This college is comprised of one
elector for each Senator aud Bcpro
ionlativo from tho States' respectively.
In previous Presidential elections, for
instance, Utah, since Statehood, has
had threo electors. This number is uot.
increased by tho women votes. Utah
will havo at the Presidential election of
next year four electors, two on account
of its Senators aud two for tho two
representatives .which it will havo in
tho lower .house of Congress: Tho ap
portionine.nl of Representatives is made
on the. aggrogato population of the
Stale, and not on tho number of votes
cast. New York Stato at tho Presiden
tial election of next year will have
forty-fivo electoral votes, two ou ac
count of its two Senators, and forty
three on account of its forty-throo Rep
resentatives, this being the number ac
corded to tho Stato on .the new appor
tionment based on tho census of last
year. If New York should in the mean
time paas a law giving its women tho
right of suffrage just an they have in
Utah and other suffrage States, New
York would still have Its forty-five elec
toral votes, no more, no less; so that
no injustice is done to any State by
reason of any extensions or limitations
of the suffrage which any Stale sees
fit to impose.
Thcro is no National recognition of
the legality of women votes, just as
thcro is no National qualification for
voters. Tho voters cast thoir ballots
under the Slate law, by virtue in each
Stato of the statutes passed governing
elections. The National Government
has nothing whutevcr to do with it,
save thut the National constitution re
quires Congress to guarantee to ovcry
Stato a republican form of government;
and as long as Congress finds no reason
to interfere on this account, tho States
arc Jeff; lo manage the matter entirely
by and for themselves. It can hardly
be claimed that Ihc extension of tho
suffrage to women is a denial of a re
publican form of government, and as
long as no such denial is cither claimed
or can be insisted upon by reason of
that extension,-ihc Nntional authority
has no foundation upon which to act.

It has been announced that he would

on these, it being conceded ou all

everything except tho ' bill revising

tariff a contention is ntiido that the
President was wrong, and that, the ar

ury, that the President made an irre

A Democratic President.
Special Cable to The Tribune.
GENEVA. Sept. 16. M. Marc Ruche t.
president of the Swiss republic for the
year 1911, Is so democratic In his tastes
that he Is often found In the Hotel Berne
or In pome more modest cabaret, where
he sits In his shirt sleeves, talking to
visitors from the country or engaging In
"jass," an Innocent card game, the losor
usually paying for the other's coffee.
Ruchet is the son of a schoolmaster and.
like most Swiss presidents, is a lawyer.
His salary for the year of official life Is
only $3200.

N.15W YORK, Sept. 1G. Catholics are
calling attention to the fact that with

Forty new summer conferences Is tho

Foreign Missions Make Gain.
The Methodist foreign mission board,
representing the large Methodist body
of the north. Is $101,000 ahead of the
same time last year In Its financial re

The foreign bonrd asks Methodists for

field this year $1.11-1,000. Last year

while Methodist women gave, through

more than $2,100,000. The women raise
and spend money for missions, adminis

money over as in the case of most oth

This year both home and foreign
Methodist board? hold their annual
meetings in Denver. The date of the
meeting of the home board is November
10, and of tho foreign November 15.

a&passln.

LIEUTENANT SMITH
CLAIMS INNOCENCE
By Associated Press.
SAN FRANCISCO. Sept. 1C Lieuten
ant Roy C. Smith, recently attached to
the: Saratoga, the flagship of the Asiatic
squadron, came ashoro today from the
Japanese liner Shinyo Maru. He said
that while he had no Intention of recon
sidering Ills leslgnatlon from the navy he
Intends to muke a personal appeal to the
Feeretary of the navy In Washington.
Lieutenant Smith said he. resigned nt the
request of Admiral Murdock without mak
ing a fight before a court-martial on ac
count of the Ferlonsness of the charge?.
The word of other officers alone stood
against his denial, he explained, and as
his own statement was not believed no
felt that he could no longer remain In
the navy.
Lieutenant Smith says that he was the
victim of circumstances and ho hopes
lo clear his name after presenting his
case at Washington. As the lieutenant
stepped ashore he was met bv Lieutenant
Charles P. Huff of the naval training sta
tion with iho request that he remain In
confinement on t ho receiving ship Pensa
cola until the navy depart ment should
be heard from. He consented.

Adjournment-
Noted. Sociologist Hero.
Miss Amy Brown Eaton of New
York,, a noted socialistic worker, is in
the city collecting material for a work
on "Eugenics." She is collaborating
with C. B. Davenport, of the bureau or
eugenics of the Carnegie- Institute in
Washington. Miss Eaton will appear
on the programme of the state federa
tion in Ogden in Oetobor, in tho dis
cussion to follow tho paper of Mrs.
P. N. Cook on "Eugenics."
Mies Eaton is a woman of rare cul
ture and has given much tinio to the
studj of sociological conditions, spend
ing several years in the slums of New
York. She is a graduate of Brown
university and has a master's degree
from the University of Pennsylvania.
She will remain in Utah a year, mak
ing her headquarters in Salt Lake,
and will bo an addition to Snlt Lako
club circles.

Cost of War Is High.
Special Cable to Tho Tribune.
CBTTIGNE. Sept. lfi. A paper which
has been drawn up here at the ministry 1
of finance contains some Interesting fis
sures with respect to the expenses In
curred by Montenegro In consequence of
the Albanian revolt. The tptal loss Is
estimated at n.000,000 kronen, or about
13.0-10,000. nearly twice the sum at which
the annual budget Is balanced. Of this
sum $130,000 Is put down to military
charges and 5140,000 to the direct cost
of supporting the refugees. The nation
al subscription on behalf of tho Alban
ians amounted to 525.000. The remain
ing sums represent the official estimate
of Indirect losses to trade and Industry.

Special Cable to The Tribune,
ST. PETERSBURG. Sept. 1C If the
youmc czarwitch Is not a second Pctr
tho Great It will bo through no fault of
his father. Tho Czar Is a devout believer
ln spiritualism, and. as I have before,
stated. Iia3 been I old by the spirits his
mnall son was tho reincarnation of tlfc
founder of tho Russian empire.
The" Czar has given orders that nothing-
shall bo dona to hinder his son's dis
position in be anothcV Peter the Grout.
Ho can have all the boats ho wants, both
tov and full-sized, lie is allowed to ko
aboard Russia's row remaining warships
and ordor all tho yuns to he fired lo
suit his fancy. He has tho crews of the
ships called out and drilled for his cn
terlalnmcnu which gives him an Immense
amount, of pleasure as It would to most
other children of his age.
In his desire lo favor the development
of his son thc Czar has passed a great
deal moro lime ot sea than hu earo3 to
do. for he Is not. a good sailor. He spent
a considerable part of last year on his
great yacht, tho S'tandnrt. which Is
lUtfi! out as a warship. Thc little Czar
witch dresses as a. blue.iackct. Ho wears

perial Guard a picked body of men. If

erybody known, and the nolso not only

tendant came back with the Information,

The officers know the Czar's orders,

MllllOHS SPENT II
KICK ABROAD
Previous Records Broken by
Tourists From This
Country.
LABOR LEADERS CLEVER
Mann and Tillett, Prominent
in England's Strike, Have
Eventful Careers.
BY PAUL LAMBETH.
Special Cable to Thc Tribune.
LONDON. Sept. 1G The flood of trav
el still sweeps westward In pracllcally
unatated volume. Thc labor troubles and
tho consequent disarrangement of ship
ping schedules caused a great congestion
of homeward bound Americans which has
not yet been fully relieved. Every west
ward bound passenger steamer Is crushed
to Its limit and It will be some weeks
yet before this travelers from beyond the
sea will be taken home.
All passenger records have been broken
for the past month. In one week just
after tho strike was settled fully 50.000
passengers left England for home. This
only Includes Americans, not taking Into
consideration thc great volume of emi
grant traffic.
It would be Impossible even lo esti
mate the wealth left in Europe this year
by traveling Americans. That ll. runs
away up In the mlllolns, pounds, not dol
lars, Ip certain. It Is certain that It tops
all previous records.
Thc two dominant figures in the re
cent labor troubles on the side of thc
men were Tom Mann and Ben Tillett.
They arc perhaps the most Influential
men in England today In the ranks of or
ganized labor.
Labor Leaders -Had Eventful Careers.
It Is a curious fact that they both
have been rolling stones whose lives
would furnish plenty of material for af
fection. Few men have had a more strenuous
struggle for existence than Tillett, who
Is general secretary of the Dockers'
union. As a boy he traveled the country
with a circus troupe, afterwards being
sent to work In a brickyard. At 12 years
of age ho was onc of the crew of a fish
ing smack. Then he was apprenticed lo
a bootmaker, served for some lime ln the
navy, and after helng Invalided Horn the
service, and making some voyages In
merchant, vessels, settled down to labor
organizations. He organized the Dockers'
union and his interferences with foreign
strikes have not been relished by Bel
gian or German authorities, who Impris
oned him and ejected him from their
territories.
Tom Mann, tho strikers' general, was
born at Folcshill. "Warwickshire, where
he worked In the coal pits as a boy. He
came to Birmingham with his parents,
and obtained work in an engineering
works, where he made so much- progress
that he was soon ablo lo lake a position
at Thorneycroffs as an expert torpedo
worker. He has since had a varied ca
reer, being a public-house keeper, a stu
dent for Ihc church, a candiate for parli
ament, a farmer In Australia, and a pub
lic lecturer. Last year ho was elected
president of the Dockers' union.
Andrew Carnegie told an audience at
Liverpool the other day that he had
"taken to library forming becauso his
father did It. before him." William Car
negie's olYorts at library founding were
extremely modest as compared with thc
work of his distinguished son. In 1S3S
Mr. Carnogie's father was a. Journeyman
weaver in Dunfermline. He and two
other drivers of thc shuttle mot and
agreed to convey thc books they had In
their respective homes to ono house. The
combined libraries only figured out twenty
volumes. The pioneers were joined by
other weavers, and they agreed lo tax
themselves to the extent of a few pence
per month and from this fund purchase
now looks. The utile Institution ulti
mately blossomed Into thc Dunfermline
Tradcsmens library.
New Governor to "Entertain.
George V. Is known to bo particularly
desirous that the approaching term of the
duko of Connaught as Canadian governor
general shall be distinguished by an ef
facemunt of the ill will, more or less pro
nounced In some parts of tho Dominion,
developed toward tho United States dur
ing tho reciprocity controversy.
To this end tho duke Is expected not
only to use his Influence In moderating
tho tone of Ihc press comment hostile
to American statesmen and capitalists,
hot also lo establish "helpful social re
lations between Important Canadian and
Important American families, taking his
cue from Buckingham palace "
So alleges a usually woll-lnformed
chronicler of thc social trend In "exalt
ed circles,"
If the forecast is worth anything it
Implies that Connaught will keep open
house at Ottawa for Amorlcans of note,
on a scale quite unknown to Earl Grey
and his predecessors.
Connaught is thought eminently quali
fied by nature and convictions for a mis
sion calling for conciliation along these
lines.
A diplomat by instinct and a democrat
by preference, ho is -.ounted on to at
tract to the Dominion a class of Ameri
cans who never have been represented
adequately In the social functions at gov
ernment, house.
British statesmen of all parties deplore
the bad blood that Is tho outcome In Can
ada of misrepresentation or misunder
standing of the ulterior alms of the
United States regarding tho Dominion.
The feeling grows in London that thc
co-operation of Washington Is becoming
absolutely priceless In world politics, and
consequently that Imperial Interests suf
fer when Canadian sentiment towards
Americans Is embittered as of late.

TT A 7 ASTUNOTON Sept. 10. Over
A .10.000 miners killed in the
l United States within the past
V W ten years. 15.000 of them need
lessfy. More than 75.000 min
ers injured, many of them maimed for
life. 40,000 of whom should bo strong
men todav. Eleven thousand miners 1
and the pulmotor an ingenius device

iatel.y following; the dust explosion,
when the supposed rescuers will rush
into the smoke-filled gallery and bring
out. "victims, " npplying tho various re-
widows left with 30,000 orphan children
the result of carelessness and indif
ference. Such is the grim story of the tragedy
of the mines of this country and what
might have been done toward the sav
ing of human life had wo long ago
adopted the same standards of safety as
the countries of Europe. Truly an avail
ing story , if unpreventable, but all the
more ghastly when it is realized that
this tremendous toll of human life, of
suffering, of misery nnd privation might
have been lessened .by one-half, had the
proper precautions been taken in time.
How tp reduce this loss to the min
imum is t he problem now being consid
ercd by the Bureau of Mines, and as a
striking object lesson a great national
mine safety demonstration will be held
in Pittsburg, Pa., October 26-27, under
the auspices of this bureau, the Amer
ican Red Cross, the United Mine Work
ers of America, and the Pitsburg coal
operators' nsocintion. From 30.000 to
50,000 (miners, superintendents and oper
ators ere expected to bo present.
President Taft Secretary Fisher and
other notables will attend this meeting,
as well aa prominent men from all over
the United States. The purpose is to
demonstrate strikingly and convincingly
the possibility of cutting the mine death
rate in two, as well as effecting the
saving of millions in property loss. The
United States is still a now' country in
mining, ami has still to learn some of
the fundamental safeguards thnt, have
come io the older mining countries
through bitter experience.
J'"or example, it has .been generally
believed by both coal minors and oper
ators that coal dust could not explode
without the presence of gas. The bu
reau of Mines has demonstrated .beyond
any possible doubt that bituminou-Tconl
dust alone it more of a menace to tho
miner than fire damp, f'oal dust has
boon the causo of a big majority of the
mysterious explosions in . coal mines in
the las: few years, and the Bureau of
Mines will demonstrate this beyond
question at the Pittsburg meeting." On
the 26th there will be an actual ex
plosion of coal dust in the experiment
mine belonging to the bureau, where
condiiions similar to all coal mines arc
to bo found. Black powder will .be used,
and a "blown out" shot will bo pro
duced. On the 27th another dust ex
plosion will be staged on Forbes Field,
the Pittsburg base ball park, with a
capacity of .'lO.OOfA Here a temporary
steel gnllery will be erected nnd the
coal dust placed infiide and exploded
in sight of thu multitude.
The program includes a thorough dom
oust ration of the recuf apparatus of
hf bureau, including the- oXgm helmet
viving apparatus to real men. There
will be contests in bandaging .broken
limbs and stauncliing tho flow of sev
eral arteries, and a complete exploita
tion of every feuturo of the bureau's
rescue work.
The first-aid-to-the-injured feature is
considered extremely important among
niinere. As a rule, when a miner is in
jured he is far in the mine. A. fnctory
workman can be quickly rushed to the
hospital, but the miner may have to
be hulf-cnrried or dragged on a rude,
stretcher for a mile or more underground
before the trip to the hospital starts. For
this reason it is regarded of the great
est importance to the miner to. know

cation of six months, most of which he

vlto, just across the bay from Manila.

casions he, does ro there It is generally

:' tion Can' Follow In
telligently.. The following Interesting discussion of
the present industrial Ills of tho nation,
end suggestions for relief, are had IiV' the
lost weeic's market letter of James A.
rollock & Co.:
The general securities markets show
continued weakness, but after such a
long and drastic decline tho downward
symptoms should soon disappear and a
moderalo recovery sot lnt Unauestlpn
0 ably thoro has been a great dual of what
. Is termed "scientific selling," and appar
ently It has been more of a liquidating
market than a bear market, but there Is
jcottlng to bo a little too much company
on tho selling side to suit up. The
pendulum of prices swings both Tvays
even In times of. depression.
The business of the country Is at a
standstill on account- of lack of confidence
in the future. "Enterprise has ceased and
no one will undertake anything now. Tho
manufacturers, builders and railroads re
fuso to go ahead with their ordinary busl
Pfl ireas In tho way of buylnp supplies. That
PPI -which la absolutely necessary- Is pur-
PR chased and no more. If this condition
continues tho arteries of trade will suffer
from paralysis and dry rot. The root of
the evil Is lack of confidence brought
about, by the attempt of theoratlcal law
makers " to make rules and regulations
tfor the conduct of business conditions
Jthat arc twenty years ahead of their
'Ideas. The great business men and tho
Industries they represent have for years
been assailed by government and politi
cians, and this has been duo to the fact
that tho latter have heen so far behind
the business band wagon that they could
not keep In step with tho march of pros
fcess. Results Are Seen.
Tho obstacles of ignorance and preju
dice havo brought the Inevitable and just
reward In the evidence now all too ap
parent of the coming slowing down of
the groat engines of Industry. Tho gen
eral business of tho country Is becoming
depressed and surely will not again he
come active while the great enterprises
of the country languish. There will be
no chango In conditions until tho pcoplo
of the country awake to the fnet that
they have been following false lenders and
proceed to place tho brand of disapproval
upon political demagogues. It ,1s the groat
energy and Industry 6f the business mon
of- the country that has made It the com
mercial wonder of the nations of .tho
world, and not the politicians. What
benefit will tho country derive If It suc
f'Cnds Id driving out -of it severnl hundred
multl-mllHonalres with their masterly
abilities? Surely there Is not another
country on th- globe that will not wel
come them with their brains and money.
The people may be forced to make a
choice between the politicians who live
upon them and the great captains of in
dustry. who furnish the basis of prosperity
and livelihood for all. The shadow of the
1 bread lino will probably hasten the dc-
clblon. Capital has been harassed until
It has become timid, but we hope and
liejlcv this Is but a temporary condition
and that tho sphlt of fair play and great
cctroge thai bus vitalized the commercial
lift; of this great America" still exists and
j that common sense win again prevail.
There are grievances to be adjusted and
evils to be eradicated, and tho quicker the
thinking people of the country take up
the work of educating the masses and
bllenclng the demagogues the sooner will
the business of tho cpuntry return to a
normal activity.
Logical Remedy.
The first .thing to do Is to put the
quietus on tho legal parasites who live
upon the fortunes and misfortunes of the
public. About OO per cent of our con
gressional representatives are lawyers or
professional men. If tho voters of the
country will retire about SO per cent of
this class and fill their places with an
equal number of business and working
men wo will probably get a few sane laws
placed upon the statute books for the
conduct of commercial business. The
laws should "he so simple -that there will
be no reason for misunderstanding, and
they should be made not only to control
but to protect the business Interests.

COAL LAND VALUES j
OF GOVERNMENT
Under the present schemo of classify
ing government coal land 56,089.211 acres
of wlthdrnwn land had been, on August
1. .examined In geologic detail and classi
fied by the United States geological sur
vey. Tho landB found to contain work
able coal beds aggregated 1G.S73..370 acres.
These lands, In 10-acrc tracts, have been
appraised by the survey at a total valua
tion of 711.093.537, In prices ranging
from the minimum figurd stated in the
coal law S10 or$20 an acre, according
to whether the land is located within
fifteen miles of the railroad to figures
of over $-100 an aero where the thickness
of the coal beds may aggregate (JO, 80,
or 100 feet, or even more.
Tho government valuations accord In a
general-way with the market values of
private coal lands In the west, although
as a matter of fact they aro somewhat
more liberal to tho purchaser. Four hun
dred, dollars an acre may seem a high
price for Undo Sam's coal land, which
a few years ago might have 'been bought,
for $20 an acre. However, the geological
survey's plan of claaslllcallon and valua
tion contemplates that the government
should receive at least a reasonable re
turn for Its coal, admittedly the most
useful rock mineral In Its possession.
When it Is understood that an aero
with, say, a 40-foot coal bed or seam,
contains approximately 72,000 tons of
coal and an acre with 100 feet of coal
contains 160,000 tons, the price asked by
the government, instead of being exorbi
tant, Hueins, on the other hand, hardly
sufficient.. On land having a thickness
of SO feet of coal 5100 an acre would be
less than 3 cents a ion. In reality, un
der the survey regulations which con
sider depth of the coal, number of beds,
quality, nnd other physical details, the
prices asked for many areas containing
80 feet of coal arc equivalent to nearer
i than 3 cents a ton.
At the minimum prices which were in
effect before the government "withdrawals
of coal lands, tho 16.S73.370 acres above
referred to would havo been priced at
only" L'6C.652,'iSl, the difference In favor
of tho public revenue at tho new prices
being therefore $415,310,106. Under the
provisions of tho national Irrigation, law
the proceeds from all Hales of coal "land
aro credited to the "reclamation fund," so
that government Irrigation has, as It
were, a consldorablo trust fund for fu
ture operations-

ENTERING MARKETS
James A. Pollock & Co.. bankers and
brokers, furnish the following, received
over their prlvntc wire yesterday after
noon: Palno. Webber & Co.. BostonThere
wns a much more cheerful feeling and
better tone to the local market. De
mand for better class of stocks was fair,
with tho supply exceedingly small. Lake
was tho strong feature, selling up easllv
lo 20. Pressure was removed In the New
York market and shorts had to climb
for stocks In covering. There is ho par
ticular reason to kcl very bullish on tho
market at this time, but tho bear side
has been played to a standstill and the
level Is too low to make that operation
very profitable. Believe In buying tho
better class of poppers on a scale from
this level.
Logan it Bryan. New York The week
closes with a much better feeling In evi
dence both horc and abroad. The chance
In sentiment, though by no means unani
mous, resulted primarily from a more
cheorful feeling relative to the outcome
of the Moroccan affair. The New York
stock market has been forced lo absorb
n larce amount of liquidation, not only
for domestic but also for foreign ac
count, wl-Jch tended to precipitate, dras
tic declines in view of the fact that the
Investment inquiry has been very small
and banking support not constant
It Is true Unit the labor, situation is
still such as will bear close watching
and the political outlook Is suggestive of
further strife, but the strong point at
the moment appears to be tho banking
situation, which fundamentally Is much
more satisfactory than has been tho case
for quite a period. Advices as to the
state of trade denote slight Improvement
and more confidence, 'but the conservat
ism which has been in evidence for quite
a period seemingly has dictated a hand-to-mouth
policy on the part of retailers
and In addition collections are reported
as being slow.
Competition in iron and steel lines has
become rather keen and rjrlce cutting on
finished products on a larger scale has
been Indulged In. It Is not Improbable
that the various steel companies, while
handling a fair volume of business, will
reflect a. decrease In net earnings as a
result of .thn foregoing. The recent buy-
Ing of securities at advancing prices has
been primarily In 'tho nature of short
covering, but the outside: demand has
Increased somewhat and it Is not Im
probable that further .rallying- tendencies
will be displayed. But It may be well
not to follow the upturns too closelv. as
reactions will doubtless occur quite fre
quently, as the trading- is mostly of a
professional character and stock taken
for supporting purposes will doubtless ih
marketed as opportunities are nrescutcd.

MILL MAY BE ERECTED
Many Experts Give Utah Sec
tion Recent Visits Say
Reports.
V
The Green River Dispatch gives an ac
count of tho. sale of twenty-ono tons of
uranium and vanadium oros by Forsma'n
& Ward lo the American Vanadium com
pany of Baltjmoro. William ICearns, tho
representative of the company, was in
the field to sccuro this shipment for his
firm, and the shipment will be made to
Liverpool. Tho shippers received 1-20
per pound for their rock.
It Is rumored in Green River Unit F. J.
Cameron of Philadelphia Is to erect a
reduction works In that vicinity for the
treatment of rare metal ores, and this, If
true, emphasizes the growing Importance
of Utah as a rare-metal field. The Dis
patch savs that this rumor Is made
plausible by tho fact that Mr. Cameron
rac'ontlv secured an optldn from F. S.
Pusoy 'for the purchase of. the lat.tcr's
sulphur mines at San Rafael. The price
of this option is said to be $150,000.
Tho Pusey sulphur mines conlaln an
unlimited quantity of the highest grade
sulphur, assaying ST per cent nine -also
sonic gold. The sulphur Is needed In tho
reduction qf the Joint oxides Hmt will be
handled at tho proposed mill. Mr. Cam
eron already operates a similar mill In
Philadelphia.
A great many assays of Hie Son Rafael
Reef uranlum-vanadluni ores have been
shown, ranging all the way fro m7.20 per
cent Joint oxides up to 29 per conl. Three
apsays were made by different metal
lurgists In different cities, on the ore In
the twonly-one-ton car which lcavesthis
week for Liverpool; they ranged 7.20,' 7.32
and 10.F7 per cent.
No loss than three experts have re
cently examined San Rafael Reef mines
and all have expressed groat surprise at
tho richness of the ores as the veins go
Into the hill. There have been somo thirty
or forty claims located along the reef and
ore cropplngs are very plainly seen for
three and a half miles. Strangely, all of
the cropplngs arc at about the same level
about I1S0 feet above sea lovel, or 100
feet higher altitude than Green River
station.
Radium is made from uranium and the
vanadium is used to harden steel, only
one ton of It being needed for each 1000
tons of stool. This Increases the life of
steel about threefold.

"That the state of Utah needs a' new
silver and lead producing camp to In
crease Its prestige among the nroduclng
states Is not to be denied.' nnd tho most
promJslng-looklng- section today : Is 'the
Santanuln camp, whero freauent find
ings of fino-grade ore are bolnc made."
said Joseph Ulmer. the mining, engineer
and Keneral manager of the santnqum
Contral compnny. This district Ih easily
reached, being- located In tho Wasatch
range of mountains ahout seventy miles
south of Salt Lake City. Santaciuin is
the railroad point on tho Snlt Lake Ron to.
from which point it is not over four miles
to tho heart of tho active and accom
plishing properties. ;
Mr. Ulmer says that In addition to uis
property there are a number df others
hard at work, among which are the fcan
taquln Chief, Union Chlof. Eva. Syndi
cate. Spring Lake. Englo Conner. Orari
Ito. Hlgglnson and many others; The
camp Is full of prospectors and no other
section of tho state presents greater op
portunities today.
The. great fissure vein of the Union
Chief property continues across the Cen
tral group-of Mr. Ulmer and associates
for 4500 feet, these two properties- end
lining north and south. A new tunnel
Is being driven to cut this, vein and ore.
Is expected In 150 feot from the .present
face. Work will be continued all win
ter. Two new strikes of splendid silver and
lead oro on the Eva and tho lligglnson
properties are creating- no end of Interest
In that section and tha news has stirred
up consldorablo Interest In this city also..
The Eva has ten .feet of ore which Mr.
Ulmer pronounces fino material for the
smelters. Tho lligglnson find Is olong
the same fissure, but at a distance of one
and a half miles from the Union Chief,
showing the great length of tho leading
vein of the district.

ment of Morocco Dis

By Associated Press.
CHICAGO. Sept. 16. Optimism as to
an oarly settlement of the Morocco dis
pute acted today In favor of lower prices
for wheat. Tho close was 5c to 5 So
under last night. Net declines formed tho
rule, too. In all the other leading staples
corn, lc to 55?'8c; oats, kftlc to fiic
and hog products, 7Jc to 60c,
Tho wheat market, hero followed the
lead of Liverpool and one of the prin
cipal causes of the weakness at the
.British port was confidence thnt tho
African cloud would soon be dispelled.
Then, too, French, Gorman and Russian
crop reports were bettor than had been
expected Pressure of Canadian and Aus
tralian wheat at Liverpool had also a
roundabout bearing hero. Liberal flour
sales at St. Louis brought about a tem
porary upturn, hut prices again receded,
owing to poor cash demand. Tho close,
however, was steady December ranged
between ?5ic and 95P,c, with last snles
ItfVic down at 9555'95?c. Corn was weak
under selling by belated longs, who noted
the excellent weather conditions for the
growing crop. December fluctuated be
tween 633c and G45c, closing weak l5c
off. at 63ftfi'64c.
Cash grades were easy; No. 2 yellow
sold at 6?.lvGiclc.
Reciprocity talk made oats heavv. De
cember touched as high and low" levels
45ifi)455c nnd 445c, with the close 5c net
lower at 45c.
Much commission selling weighed on
provisions. The outcome was a decline
all around pork. 60c; lard, 71c to 15f?
171c. and ribs, 7c to 25c.
By Leased Wire to Tho Tribune,
CHICAGO, Sept. 115, Flat, stale and
unprofitable was the ceneral verdict of
the day's speculative business in grain.
Trade was slack to weariness and many
holders of the various grains for future
deliver were showing their tired feel
ings bySchnnnlng their loads In the vari
ous pits. At the close wheat was from
ic to 5(0Sa lower and the decline in
corn and oats was practically lower.
Provisions had' a heavy appearance
most of the day and had a sharp break
near the session's close.

jB "Chapter VII.," "Transmission Elc-

els. shafts nnd gears, bolts nnd pul
j leys, and clutches.
jB Chapter VflT., "Boarings," describes

IH Chapter IX., "Lubrication," X.,

les." XIV.. "Miscellany. " and XV.,

riod of hysterical emotions she burns

B lions, and confesses that ho is not in

BBj her late husband, and is rujocted also

BMBf her eye on tho gardener, a peasant

BB to cover her indiscretions morn di's-
'BBB erectly. As wo. look at it, the book is

sol f, depending no longer upon his for
mer connection with Robert Louis Ste
venson fo gain him a hearing. In this
novel, Matt Broughton visits the South
Seas and finds there on a lonely island
something more romantic than buried
treasure, the revival or incarnation of
a great European imperial scandal. A
succession of extraordinary and sensa
tional events works out to a conclusion
which is the inevitable outcome. The
story jumps back to America, and tho
whole of it. is distinctly devoted to the
idea of the desirability of adventuro
for adventure's sake, and to tho joy
of it for what it brings. Mr. Osbonrne
has done no better work than is found
in this volume, and every reader of it
will join in acclaiming him for the
clmrui and beauty of it.
AN INDIAN WAIF.
Yellow Star, a Story of TSnst and West.
By rClulne Goodale Eastman. Willi il
lustrations by AriRcl Do Cora and Wil
liam Lone Star. Published by Little.
Brown, and Company. Boston.
Hero wc huvo the story of Yellow
Star or Stella, an unknown waif found
alive in tho arms of its dead mother
after the battle of Wounded Knee. Tho
story is told by Mrs. Eastman", who has
extraordinary, clear, and accurate
knowledge of Tndinu life and charac
ter, and she uses that knowledge and
her great skill as a writer to tell tho
stor- of that unknown Indian child.
Tho babo is brought to a New England
village by her adopted mother, a wid
ow of a missionary to tho Indians. The
Indian child becomes one of tho most
popular girls in tho village, leading all
in schoarship, in grace, and in resource
fulness. After completing her course at
the Academy sho goes back to her own
people in Dckota a field matron for
the government. The story is an en
gaging one, very beautifully told.
THE PAIR AND THE CRISIS.
Dividhur Waters. By I. A. R, Wylic.
The Bobbs-Morrill Company. Publish
ers. Indianapolis.
This is a sort. of. international story,
by the author of "The Native Born,"
which had a good run among novel
readers while it was fresh. Tlio pres
ent volume is the. story of a young Eng
lish girl married to a German army
officer. Tho characters are made very
much alive, and they aro so drawn as
to appeal irresistibly to the reader; but
beneath the story itself there is tho
underlying themo of tho antagonism, be
tween tho English and the Germans,
and tho story works upon those divid
ing lines so as to lead up to what maii
supposo to bo the inevitable war be
tween Germany and Great Britain. The
heroine of the slory, while married to
a man who is completely filled with the
Gccrinau ideals, retains her interest in
and devotion to her native country, and
is humiliated when flic crisis comes and

war which was impending "becauso she
finds herself unprepared for it. Tho
story is one of great vividness, and is
told in excellent vein..
IN EARLY DAKOTA."

lished by Harper & Brothers, Now

FINE BOOKS FOR BOYS.
Firebrands. By Frnnk E. Martin and
George m. Davis, M. D. With Illus
trations from Photographs. Little,
Brown, and Company, Publishers, Bos
ton. This volume was written for tho spe
cial purpose, of teaching children how
fo avoid setting fires, how to extinguish

til help conies. There aro twenty-five
stories in tho book, and each one tells

of millions of dollars aro wasted in

every year. It is commonly known
that a large proportion of this loss is
due to carelessness, thoughtlessness, and

ing in tho aggregate. These fire stories

ner of its writing is admirable.

Improvement. Financial conditions during the past
wcok have evidenced practically no
change from I he situation of the pre
ceding week, according to local bankers
and business men, although it is gen
erally agr.oed that tho money market
has been steady null satisfactory with
signs of a. coming impetus. Tho unset
tled status of the labor agitation and
tho temporary drop in tho prices of
sheep and lambs aro said to have in
fluenced many lines of business, and tho
usual short "lull prior to the renewed
efforts that are brought, with tho fall
season litis beon felt.
During the week the circulation of
money lias been increased, through more
activo business among the building so
cieties, investment- firms and tho moving
of bank certificates. Business mou re;
gard as commendable the absence- of
speculative- features in all lines. Money
'has been obtainable on about tho samo
basis as has existed for tho past two
or three weeks. Jtatcs of interest have
not been high for the season..
Private reports on the crops, indi
cate that there will be much larger
yields' than was suggested i.n the gov
ernment report of August .1. Local
financial circles have boon iutlueiiccd by
tho action of eastern markers, which
anticipate improved conditions by vir
tue or the more favorable crop outlook.

vestigations and estimates that tho corn
viebl will b6 from 2,700,000 to 2,S00,000
bushels, as compared with 2,(i00,000
bushels or lets as gh'en out 1)3' the gov
ernment's report.
With the new anticipation in the east
over the crop yields, and the generally
good condition of crops in the west, the
broad financial markot, according to
nroiniucut and well-posted bankers, sees
better times ahead of it, and there- is
a more pronounced feeling of case in
money circles, coupled with a healthier
flow of business through most channels.
Depressions in some lines have been
felt, but in Hie broad generality condi
tions aro said to be good,

LARGEST HOME OF
II PICTURES
Remodeling of Max Daniels
Theater Will Place II in
Front Rank.
By the expenditure of something over
$75,000 in remodeling and improvement
work, Max Daniels, propriolor of what
was formerly the Bungalow theater on
Slate street near Third South, intends
lo make of the establishment, one of the
largest moving picture houses in tho
world. The completed structure will bo
known as the 7Janiels t healer, and is ex
pected to open for business about Jan
uary 1 to the popular 5-ccnt admittance
charge.
The theater will cover a space of 52
feet bv 235 feet, facing on Stale street
and Floral avenue. The entire building
will be used for the theater, and there
will be no sforos flanking the entrances.
According to I he plans and specificii;
tions, which are now in the hands of
Architect A. J. Headland, who is in Ihe
east gathering data and ideas for the
building, the seating capacity Will be
31500. It is said that the next largest
moving picture house is in Londdn,
where the capacity is 3600 seats. Tho
plans call for a strictly fire-proof struc
ture, with concrete floors, ceilings and
walls. Under a contract with the Pa
cific Coast Underwriters' Fire lOxtin
guishing company the new theater will
be equipped with automatic tiro extin
guishers of the latest practical type. It
is declarod that a fire would be impos
sible under the arrangement.
Particular care w.ill be given lo the
matter of ventilation. By means of a
special cooling plant and "fresh air sys
tem, the air in tho theater will be of
healthy circulation, changing every
minute or so. Tho building will be pro
vided with light and heat by the in
stallation of its own electric plant.
There will bo ladies' waiting rooms, spe
cial apartments for babies and baby ve
hicles, smoking rooms and cloak rooms.
A maid will be in attendance upon the
lady patrons. A porter will be sta
tioned in front of tho entrance to caro
for automobiles. A feature of the es
tablishment will bo the numerous exits.
The Chicago Decorative company will
mnkc all decorations. The cliairs will
be leather-seated. Tho highest type of
moving pictures will bo shown, and an
orchestra of fifteen men is promised.
The present house, which is now be
ing transformed into the new theater,
was built three years ago by John Cort,
who sold his lease to tho Bungalow the
ater company. This firm re-loasod the
place to II. "R and W. S. Rami. The
last leaso has been canceled and the
money returned. Mr. Daniels also an-

is the estimate of J. C. Stay, connty

Big Demand for Peaches.
Peaches were the feature on the local
markot yesterday, and Mr. Stay esti
mates thnt there were close to
SOOO cases for sale, at prices ranging
from forty cents to sixty cents. Tho
prico he considers abnormally low con
sidering the comparatively scant supply
of poaches that aro in the country.
" I believe," he naid. "that the price
of sugar lui3 much lo do with this, and
that tho people do not care to put up
their usual supply with sugnr worth
what it is today.
"I i;an say, though, that I think that
when you can get poaches of the 'four
six' size for sixty cents a case, or loss,
that it is cheap. Tho present is about
the height of the peach season."
Something of the size of the supply
on hand. i5000 cases, can be gained
from computing that it means more than
three full carloads of peaches. The 1,
500 retail buyers had considerable
choico to pick from at that.
"T uevcr saw the market looking
cleaner or prettier,' ' said Mr. Stay, in
roferring to tho quality of the goods on
tho market this morning. By "clean
er" Mr. Stay refers to freodom from
disoaso or infection.

teen bushels of apples that had the

street, market. They had teen shipped

bor Jensou, of Hyrum. t

tery Over Shooting by Al
j leged Highwayman.
Special to The Tribune.
OttDKN. Sept. lit. Lying at the Dec
hospital, hovering between life and death
i with n. bullet wound in his left breast
since Inst Thursday night, Theodore
Faust, 2D years of age, living at 21 OS
Tyler avenue, tells a wftlrd story of hav
ing been attacked and shot down by a
highwayman, while the Ogden pollen, evi
dently disbelieving tho. story, bnvo sup
pressed the facts of the shooting.
According to the hoy'B story he had
Just left his home and was walking near
the corner of Twenty-third street and
Tyler avenue when a highwayman
stepped from the dark and. without a
word, fired point blank at him. Faust

inal case.

nounced 1)3' the directors of the M. H.

Tho decision of tho board of direc
tors to put up a sixteen-story building

ences between W. S. Eames of tho firm

now building will be ready for occu

Have Applications for Space.
The determination to erect a sixteen
story structure was reached after care
ful deliberation, and is an expression
of tho faith felt Ivy tho directors of
the M. JT. Walker Ifealtj' company and
Walker Brothers, bankers, in the prom
ising future of Salt Lake. The direc
tors yesterday announced that a great
many applications for office space in

cupied when finished.
Tho first sk3-scrnpcrs of the larger

ing is a ton-story structuro, as is also

With its main body extending upward

dome, the new Walker building will

classification of middle-sized' cities to
that of metropolitan centers.

tho same height as the proposod Walker
structure. Tho highest edifice in San
Francisco at present is the Call build
ing, a sixteen story structure, excluding

geles and Omaha there arc 110 "buildings
that would classify in height with the

niakcup the big. majestic skyscraper of

nounced, it has been authoritatively

ings havo been received and approved

dent of the Walker Brothers nankin"
house, who is also tho head of the realty

ker Kealty company was rcceutly incor
porated Mr. Walker gavo over the site

Mr. Walker, in not having been influ

oi the city. The now structure will not

Purchased Forty Years Ago.
"The property on tho northeast cor
nor of Main nnd Second South streets
was purchased by Walker brothers in
1871, and became my personal property
about thirty years ago." said Mr. Wal
ker yesterday. "It has been my plan
for many -years not to build a' large
structure, on this comer until the time
should be ripe for a building that
would be a credit to nn- city. Mv life,
from boyhood days, has been, spent in

mulated Avhat T have. T have tho ut
most faith in tho future of the city.'
and tho erection of the sixtcen-sloy
building on this corner is "a proof of

'The. men who, with Mr. Walker, form
the directorate of the realty firm, are

ate of the banking firm. However, the
two corporations are independent, and
the two institutions are operated alto

VICTIM OF MORPHINE
ATTEMPTS SUICIDE
Harry Kemp, a morphine fiend nnd a
pcttv thief who was serving a sentence
In tho city jail for vagrancy, cut the
radial artery and tho radial nerve on
the wrist of his left arm at 2 o'clock
yesterday afternoon and came near blood
ing to death before-the doctor. H, B.
Spraguc. arrived. Jailer Tom Gillespie
administered first aid and probably saved
tho man's life. Dr. Spraguo stopped the
flow of blood and sewed up the wound
and Kemp was dismissed ironi tho Jnll
and given until midnight to get out. of
the city.
Jailer Gillespie says that tho drug
fiends (thero an eighteen of the.ni now
In the city jail) had been making- a nolso
and giving trouble all day. Thuy go wild
when deprived of their drugs and would
do anything to get It. They generally
find, some way In which to smuggle it Into
the jail, but there are. so many of them
there now that the supply smuggled In
this way evidently would not go around.
In these straits It Is not uncommon for
them to cut themselves In this manner
In order to got under tho doctor's care In
hopes of getting access to the drug.
Kemn was shot in the leg by Patrol
man Sloater about six months ago whllo
trying to escape from a chain gang.

BOOST HOME INDUSTRY
Speakers Hold Output of the
State's Factories Can
Easily Be Doubled.
A strong plea for a closer relation
ship between the people of this state

their mutual advnntago, was made by

Commercial club at Murray lust night.

pcrit' of the factories and the prosper
it' of the individual nnd of the state

dent George S. McAllister of tho Man
ufacturers association; Secretary Dan
iel F. Collntt of the same organization,

tures that were in direct eouncctioii

Tho announcement of tho meeting at
tracted a number of men and women of

try campaign of" the Utal Improvement

ciation; Mrs. O. II. Hewlett, Mrs. D. F.

"We want to create a closer relation
ship between tho industries of this stale
and tho peoyilo of this state." said
Lewis F. Bo3'lo, the principal 'speaker.
"If we can get a better understanding
of our duty to the pcoplo and to our
selves, and will do our duty by the state,
wo will enjo a greater degree of pros
perity. Wo must support the industries
and the people who support us with
their payrolls. More than $2,000,000 a
year is sent 1)3" "the pcoplo of Utah to
the eastern states in trade. We corn
plain that we aro under the thumh of
the money powers in the cast and aro
compelled to go to tbom and beg for
money to develop our almost unlimited
resources, when we arc responsible in
tho first place for our own troubles. If
we keep the money at home we will
havo it here to develop our own re
sources. Wo -will not be compelled lo
beg the eastern mone' kings for our
own 1110 ne3
Keep Money at Home.
"Every dollar that wo send out of
this state to tho cast gives tho east
that much stronger a grip on the west.
Why not keep the money at home and
thus help ourselves? We want more
people here. Wn can't support them
unless wo can give them employment
at good wages. Wo can give tnem that
employment if we will patronize tho
Utah "manufacturers and help them to
build up the payrolls and give moro em
ployment to more men and women.
There aro 600,000 tenant farmers in the
east .who want to come into tlie west,
but they caunot corao until we can take
care of our own farmers.
" 'Support the state that supports
you' should bo the. slogan of every man
and woman iu this state. Wc do not
ask you to support the manufacturers
in this stato under every consideration.
Wo ask you to support them only when
the prices and tho riualitv of tho goods'
the" produce aro equal to tho prices
and tho goods that- are brought in from
other states. That is all the Manufac
turers association asks."
Mr. Boyl.oN gavo a brief history of the
organization of the Manufacturers as
sociation and its growth during the last
few 3'cars, and said that its purpose
was to bring the producer and the. con
sumer closer together, aud to build up
tho industries of tho state nnd promote
prosperity, lie told of tho industrial
exhibit in the Chanibor of Commerce in
the Vermont building, and of the im
mense advertising power that exhibit
has. He told of the thousands of tour
ists who have visited the exhibit and
have seen what Utah can produce in
tho factories and on the farms, and
urged Iho Murray Commercial club to
make arrangements with as littlo delay
as possible to place an exhibit of tho
fruits of Murray's industry in tho
Chamber of Commerce.

Mayor Philip Bcntz of Murrav mado
a brief address iu which he pledged tho
citv of Murray to form such tin exhibit

George S. McAllister, president of the

of progress, and delivered a convincing
