operation in tho task of building up tho
industrial side of the state. He urged
the boys to seek employment iu tho
factories nnd learn, usoful trades, and
110 urged their parents to patronize tho
factories, to give the boys oinplovmeut.
Mr. McAllister said that, there are 749
factories in the stae. producing 500
different articles. These factories pro
duced last year goods valued at $51.
000,000. If tho people of the state will
support the factories, ho said, they will

Haniel F. Collett, secretary of the as

rfir4IJj) HE glories of the coronation
I j of Eng!and"s monarclis have.
kCT-jJj been the theme of greatest
fglll interest in the eyes of all
Ma":en the world. And even In demo
cratic America we hare been a bit
dazzled thereby. The return of the
great to mediaeval brilliance of color,
and riot of gold and jewels, .for this
great occasion, is reflected in the robes
oi Fashion generally. So that all of
the world shall catch a ray or two of
the glories of nobles and kings. Coro
nation reel and king's blue arc not the
only darlincs of the mode that boast
8 royal descent For there are In
uuraerable opulent touches to he noted
in gold embossed brocades and tinsel
tassels. In beading, jeweling and heavy
embroidery that hint at the Influence
of the great and mysterious East. .
At a recent exhibition of Imported
models, four examples of the success
ful exploitation of East Indian ideas
ere noted. The first was an after
noon costume of navy blue Liberty
Satin, with Oriental "embroideries,
gleaming with meial throat?. It was
a one-piece robe effect, fastened down
the front and shirred in, at the waist
line, where a girdle of plaited satin
cords, with heavily weighted sash ends,
confined the fullness. The skirt was
left open almost to' knee height, so as
to show the ankle In walking, the1
front sections lapping across each
other. This gave a very narrow effect, i
and wrapped the garment closely
about the figure, in such a manner as
to clearly reveal its lines. This cos
tume was In low tones, relieved by
sumptuous embroideries of many col
ors, skilfully blended, and applied. In i
such a manner as to seem woven with
IH tQo fabric Itself. An evening costume,
KJ by Paquln, also hespoke the influence
Hj of East India, in motive and coloring.
Hj The foundation lining was of a pecu-
H liar shade of East Indian red chiffon,
veiled -with a medium bright blue
shade of the same material. The over
hi dress was scattered with an embrold-
Hj cred floral pattern in heavy dull blue
Hj and mauve silk, and dark blue wooden
Ml beads. A deep band, at the hem, be-
B low the chiffon tunic, was in striped
Jj silk and cotton East India tissue and
H gave the appearance of an under petti-
9yB coat The stripes were in blue, orange,
JHH black, purple, green and pale blue, and
fjjlfl gleaming with metal threads. Ap-
11 PI pllqued motives of dark blue chiffon,
llUm W,th embroIdered designs, further elab-l
lw orated this underskirt. Heading the
fRjH band, and as a sort of border to the
jllfifl chiffon tunic were dark blue wooden
liilffl beads. This was a two-pleco dress,
M in consisting of bodice and skirt, with a
njiyf girdle placed slightly above the nat-
m ural waist line, at its lowest point
HI As the girdle was wide, however, it
jflflgW Increased the short-walstcd effect. The
WW bodice was of the surplice order, with
" characteristic double crosslae lines
of the East Indian dress, and on the
right breast, falling to one side, was
a jabot of the chiffon in Indian red
and dark blue. The military sash
girdle and bands of the srarpllce front
were of changeable blue and purple
taffeta. The variety of colorB, in this
costume, was unusual, and yet so skil
fully handled as to produce a delight
fully harmonious effect
As has been noted, the general lines
of afternoon and evening costumes in
cline towards simpllclty; The high
waist line and rather narrow skirts
prevail, in the majority of models,
though there are a few which show a
leaning toward the 1830, rather than
the dlrectolrc modes. Fichu effects are
not uncommon, with here and there a
suggestion of bertha or bretelles.
Cords, tassels and fringes are wide
ly used as decoration-?, the latter be
ing especially noticeable. Naturally
with fringes to the fore, draped effects
again assert themselves. A three
piece costume recently exhibited illus
trates this tendency perfectly. It in
clined a bit toward the quaint 1S60
effects, and had, as an entirely new
feature, the much talked of balloon
sleeves, whose fullness at the elbow
was stretched on little hoops of feath
crbonc The bodice had a draped fichu
about the shoulders, bordered with
fringe. below a small white net yoke,
trimmed with tiny buttons. Lavender
blue, pernio crepe was the material
chosen for this little gown and coat
and the fringe was in the same color.
The flchu and under sleeves were of
white chiffon, and the flchu collar of
the wrap was of white wool, The
skirt of thl3 costume was in tunic ef
fect, wrapping the figure closely, and
the edges. were bordered with fringe
and heavily weighted in order to pro
duce a close, clinging effect in the
draperies. The wrap was also In the
draped style, with fringe about the
edges, the fronts draping over like
the ends of a shawl. The sleeves were
half length and across the back was a
little belt of shirring which held the
wrap in to the figure at the waist line.
Tunic effects continue in favor, em
broidery bands, beading and fringes
finishing the lower edges and the
sleeves. Bordered patterns, printed or
embroidered, offer pleasing possibili
ties of manipulation into charming
tunic costumes. KImona or butterfly
sleeves still retain their hold -upon
popular fancy, although the draped
sleeve and the balloon sleeve, which
are newer, have come to dispute their
popularity. Very long, close fitting
sleeves are a feature of many a smart
costume, suggesting early Italian styles.
Girdles, sashes and cordeliers are in
quaint harmony with the revival of
these antique modes, as arc also trim
mings of marlbou and fur. Very soft
satin and messaline and softly draping
woolen fabrics are most appropriate
in these clinging costumes, while voiles,
marquisettes, chiffon cloths, nnd crepes,
both plain and nsrured. nnnnnv in
tunics and over-draperies. " Heavy
surah silks have again made their aj
pearance in the field of fashion, after
an absence of many years, and will
find n ready welcome.
Taffeta, too, Is again modish, cos-'
tumes In this material, fringe trimmed,
which 'were one of the sensations of
the late summer, being shown as deml
toilettes, for Fall and Winter.
Short coats und close skirls, giving
the fashionable slender outlines, are
still the favorites, though skirts are
not so narrow as they have been dur
ing the past few seasons, having at
tained just the proper dimensions for
grace and ease.
Two to two and one-half yards Is an
"average measure about the hem of the
smart fall tailored skirt. Plain gored
effects are, of course, ultra modish,
but there are many pretty models,
showing pleats let in at the side from
knee to hem. Panel backs are well
nigh universal, some circular skirts or
skirts. with circular cut backs, being
about the only exceptions.
Tunic skirts of wool show simulat
ed under-sklrt effects of satin or vel
vet, the collar lapels, cuffs -and other
trimmings of the jacket matching the
underskirt.
Jackets vary from twenty-sir to
twenty-eigtit, and even in some cases,
thirty inches in length, affording a
very good range for individual selec-,
tion. In addition to the usual straight
cut coats there are many modfsh, semi
fitted jackets, better suited to the lines
of the average well-developed figure.
Very narrow English cut shoulders
appear upon the jackets of smart tail
ored suits, absolutely no fullness in
the top of the Bleeves being allowed.
A few fancy suits are cut with the
klmona or butterfly sleeve, which is
essentially dressy. Coats, with high
waist line in the back, are also seen
on costumes for dressy wear. The real
fashion features of fall snits and
coats are the handsome wide, fancy
collars, revers and broad cuffs, carried
out in a variety of novel ways. These
are often of contrasting color and fab
ric, or inlaid with velvet, braid, or
contrasting cloth.
Both double and single breasted ef
fects appear in the fall models, though
the formar, perhaps, best suits the
purposes of fancy revers and collars.
All kinds of rough, heavy materials
are smart for tailored suits, bourette
cloth, basket weaves and fancy mix
tures being the order of the day, va
ried with a few mannish suitings.
Zibellne, plain and In two-toned, ef
fects, are again In style, as might be
expected with the vogue for long-j
haired fabrics. Striped zibellne show
red or white hair lines, on dark

i
grounds. Striped suitings, of all kinds,
are very smart, for Fall and. "Winter
wear.
For dressy wear, velvet suits will
take the place of the satin models,
which achieved such a triumph during
the spring and summer. Embroidery,
on velvet. Is a new idea in adornment,
the designs being executed either in
heavy silk or colored worsted. Browns,
purples, black and white effects, grays
and dark blues are all modish and ap
propriate for the fall tailor-made. The
popularity of pretty little dresses of
wool or slrk, and of short jacket tailored
suits, renders at least one long coat
an essential of the well balanced win
ter wardrobe. Never was fashion's
display of outer wraps more lavish
than for this season, the automobile,
perhaps, having had some influence
upon the vogue for long coats.
The fifty-four Inch coat is. in fact,
preferred above all others, which is at

I HEN woman was created, ac
cording to nn old legend,
Bar tli and Heaven were
ransacked to provide her
with charms and graces,
they have been exploited
e for new articles of adorn
iieral, vegetable and animal
il'ng called upon to yield their
reasnres.
re among the oldest articles
lg which have contributed to
art and appearance of hu
The Idea of snatching the
f his four-footed brothers and
o shield his own tender and
ed skin must, have occurred
7 to prehistoric man. Even
re is a sort of primitive ap
nt rich, glossy skins, fash
to garments of the utmost
id comfort,
comlngness of furs, no less
r beauty and utility, attracts
Hons woman, for, as a set
mlnlne loveliness, they have
in equal. This Is pnrtlculnr
f natural, undyed furs, and
s fortunate when a season
iresent favors their use.
opossum, raccoon and fox
g the most 'fashionable of
rs, and are moderate enough
for the most part. Skunk,
another natural, durable and
Tely inexpensive fur, also
popularity of the last few
seasons, Mole skin is also Shown In
combination with other furs, or made
up in sets, with trimmings of passe
mentrie. The working of mole-skin
and seal in patterns is one of the
novelties of the present fur season. In
very high priced fur, mink promises
to be a leader for general wear, while
the "Coronation" has given an im
petus to ermine, as a fur for dressy
occasions. The -little tails, which are
usually sewed throughout an ermine
garment, are arranged more sparingly
on this season's creations, and in some
cases entirely omitted. Some very
broad scarfs of seal have linings of
plain ermine.
Red, gray, brown and black fox are
all used extensively, and tipped fox
is exceedingly modish. "White fox, for
evening wear, always has a large num
ber of admirers, and Is used this sea
son, as formerly, In pretty, fluffy sets,
or as a trimming to garments of er
mine. Fewer heads and tails are seen on
furs than for some years past, and
this would seem an advance in taste.
Of course, there are fox sets, and sets
of raccoon and fisher, in natural, ani
mal shades, but for the most part
broad pelerine and shawl collar ef
fects, with trimmings of passamentrle,
braid, fringe or tassels prevail, ac
companied by plain muffs, slightly
smaller than the modish ones of last
season. The best shape of muff is
undoubtedly the half-barrel, or pillow
variety, which has much of the grace
ful roundness of the barrel muff, with
out its bulk and awkwardness.
Very large pelerines of mink, er
mine and chinchilla, in effect whole
wraps of the shawl or cape variety,
are exhibited for those whose purses
can stand such luxuries, and are
among the most graceful designs of
this decade.
The woman who cannot, for any
reason, consider a full length fur coat,
will find comfort In the many pretty
short jackets of fur that arc to be the
smart thing this winter. These little
short coats are usually about the
length of the fashionable suit jacket,
which is twenty-six to twenty-eight
inches, arid they are modeled on much
the same lines. Etons of fur are also
pretty and correct, taking the place of
the large pereline. or fur scarf. These
short coats are usually of seal or Hud
son seal, broad-tall, astrachan or
baby lamb with collars and cuffs, or
other trimmings, of fuller, fluffier fur.
The Etons are sometimes bordered all
about with contrasting fur, while the
jackets show, a great variety of large
shawl collars and revers of raccoon,
fox or skunk.
Sailor collars, even, are used on
fnr coats, some In square, some In
round, and some In pointed effects.
Forty-five inch coats of fur are oc
casionally seen, and offer an excellent
compromise between the merits of the
full-length coat and the short jacket
Fichn effects in stoles of short, fine
fur, are sometimes caught at the waist
with a handsome buckle or ornament.
There is a general revolutionary sug
gestion about present fur fashions, es
pecially noticeable in fichu and cape
effects, and in broad collars and deep
cuffs.
Turbans of fur. to match muff and
scarf, or jacket trimmiugs, are also
in good style. A fur turban, worn
with a fur coat, and matching the
revers, cuffs and muff, gives a delight
fully picturesque finish to a winter
costume.
In selecting furs, one should bear
in mind that no one fur is universally
becoming. Skunk is quite generally so, 1
and mink likewise, but the gray and
black furs are not for all faces. As a
rule, they, are most becoming to
blondes and light-.complexioned people,
generally, and to those with gray hair.
Very youthful faces always look well
above light furs. Women of olive
complexion should always select a fur
with a brownish cast, unless their hair
is of a raven bla-ckness, when a black
fur may be worn. White furs are
most becoming to dark or rosy faces,
the roses of old Jack Frost, however,
render them wearable by many who
axe otherwise pale. A little study of
the possibilities of fur in enhancing
the beauty of the complexion, by con
trast, is not only interesting, but well
worth while, as It enables one to
achieve superior effects,

1Am Fashion has a relenting
I 11 I heart concealed somewhere
1 I about her modish person,
fe after all. Just when our
ViXjti.L.r tortured locks were begin
ning to stand on end, so to speak,
from constant puffing and 'stuffing and
roughing the lady graciously permits
us to coax them back to docility by
speaking up for the most simple ef
fects possible in hair dressing.
At the sa'ine time, she Is never deaf
to the plaints of the wig-makers, who
must go right on making a living, so
that unless nature has given us as
rnuch hair as a Lady Godiva most of
us will find that the present styles de
mand a luxuriance of tresses only to
be obtained by the yard- Whereas the
hair about the face must be Huffily
guiltless of pads or roughing, the gen
erous knots and twists nnd coils at
the back of the head require the ad
dition of at least a switch or two.
Very quaint and youthful is the
most popular mode of the moment
which is a charming adaptation of the
peasant hairdress. After the hair is
parted and" loosely waved the 'long
strands over the ears are wound about
in flat spiral twists, just back of the
cars, and the back portion is fprmed
into a similar twist, or into a Psyche
knot Sometimes the hair is simply
colled in Irregular strands, brought
well to the front over the ears, and
always with the contour of the head
exposed.' What is called the Flemish
Btyle is particularly hecoming to a
round, young face. The hair is parted
from the forehead down to the back
of the neck and the two sections are
then braided and coiled into circles
that almost cover the sides of tbehead.
These braids are drawn together In
the back, hut the long line of parting
is preserved.
Still another variation may be ob
tained by having a fall of curls in
the back with the circle twists at
either side. Although curls and puffs
are little used theBe days there are
many women to whom nothing is more
becoming, and In hairdresslng, above M
all, a woman should consider becom- K
ingness rather than style. A stray Ijj
curl or two resting on the neck or Just Ijj
escaping from a coll braid will do K
much to soften the features. At the ' jgj
same time nothing will Impart that u
bid maid look so successfully as any- Bm
thing resembling a corkscrew curl too 9m
near th.2 face. H
There is a marked tendency toward n
higher effects In coiffures and it Is mB
fluitevlikely that the banished pompa- Hi
dour will return again to favor The m
Psyche knot placed quite high on the Si
back of the head with a moderate H
pompadour will be considerably worn ffij
this winter. H
Thus it will be seen that a woman jjfij
may dress her hair in any 'style best w
suited to her face and consider her- fif
self quite aJa mode if she hut main- iff
tains a certain simplicity of contour, B
and though she may use as much H
false hair as'ever, if yjhe endeavors to I
obtain as natural effects as possible, H
striving to conceal its use rather than WM
flagrantly revealing it as heretofore.

IjO many lovely, creations, large
(j R and small, quaint and
feW I smart, have the milliners
pjjyliP designed for our delight
during the Inst two seasons
Chat it seemed almost out of the ques
itlon that even Paris could offer any
thing new for Fall. Yet here they
ere with us, the new models, seem
ing, as ever, smarter and more bravely
; line than the old, Also, alas, they are
eo unlike any former fashions that
remodelling last year's hat for this
year Is altogether out of the question.
' The most radical departure from all
recent millinery precedent is the very
high, pointed crown, narrow brim,
"Pierrlot" shape, which is the real
style note of the day. These crowns
eire rarely less than ten inches In
height, and very often more. They
nxe very narrow, even at the base, ana
taper to a rounded or flattened conical
top. The brims are usually pinched
In a poke across the front, or at the
back, and sometimes they are poked
fit both sides, being plain, back and
front This high, narrow, conic or
Pierriot" shape Is a very practical
one, as it fits the head well. It is de
signed to be worn without rats, puffs
or any distended, artificial coiffure ar
rangement,
i The high, narrow hat, while pre
dominant, ill not, by any means, en
tirely displace the picture hat of ample
brim and generous curves. This type
of chapchu is altogether too elegant
Jcind too becoming to a large number
of women to permit of itB being has
tily . relegnted to the limbo of things
past and forgotten. The ultra-smart
large hat will be jnst as large aB ever,
t not so ubiquitous, and will be flatter
than ever, with crown barely raised
nbovc the brim, by the scantiest al
lowance of inches.
Some medium large hats are being
fashioned with high crowns, but they
.will scarcely have the appeal of the
flatter, wider models. The large hat
Is now looked upon as exclusively a
dress affair, and not for the "highways
and byways" of the market-place,
rriila it? as it should be, and a wel
come innovation to those who have
fmffered from Its ezpansiveness in
public conveyances, elevators and the
crowded streets.
1 Old-fashioned poke bonnets are
modish still, and this is fortunate, for
j they have a certain quaint prettiness,
fercll in keeping with demure, young
jHagd or round fnces. The woman who looks
919 wril in them usually looks amazingly '
1 well, better, in fact, thnn In almost
Hm any other "type of headgear. Before
HjHgB rmsslug by' the old-fashloued poke, as
P too extreme, one should try it on, at
least, for it may prove a revelation.
These old-fashioned bonnets are some
times edged about with fringe, a
trimming in perfect harmony with
their lines. They are usually made of
velvet, and the sheltering brims are
lined or faced with taffeta, or sntin.
Velvet, by the way, is the material
par excellence for the fashionable
winter hat It is used both on pressed
and hand-made shapes, alone and in
combination with satin, taffeta, hat
ter's plus and fur felt. Uncut velvet
Is a novelty, both for hats and trim
mings, very rich in appearance, but
more resembling cord silk than ordi
nary velvet
All kinds of silks and velvets are
employed in the fashioning of winter
hats and bonnets, satins, corded silks,
moires, and plushes having been rein
forced by the advent of taffeta, into
the millinery field. The vogue' of taf
feta gowns, trlmnfed with fringes,
which took Paris by storm during the
late summer, has given an impetus to
this fabric for winter millinery. Hats
of felt and velvet are faced with taf
feta, and taffeta is sometimes pressed
upon the upper Bides of hats with felt
or velvet facings.
French crepe is new as a material
for hat facings, and-affords a delight
fully soft and becoming background
for the face. The head sizes of the
new hats remain large, and though a
bit closer than of late seasons, they
still allow the hats to sink well over
the face.
For all practical purposes this will
be quite a ribbon season, as very wide,
plain and fancy ribbons are used ex
tensively as trimmings for hats of all
kinds. Particularly Is this true of the
new, high-crowned, narrow-brimmed
hats, which are very generally trimmed
with ribbon. Ribbons show some
very handsome new, double-faced ef- .
fects, the reverse side of brighter hue
appearing in a band upon the upper
side of darker color. These ribbons
are trimmed about the new high
crowns, fold upon fold, with these
bright edges at each fold, and meeting
In a bias seam in front. The crown
is thus entirely coveTed, and at the
back rises a wired crest of ruffled rib
bon, in plume effect, very fall and
fluffy, and upstanding to an even
greater height than the crown of tho
hat Velvet and silk are also arranged
on these hats, in the same fashion as
ribbon, or in short, sharp, up-standing
bowa, covering the crowns and simu
lating wings.
Wings, faacy feathers, ana aigrette.

effects, are an almost universally pop
ular form of trimming for hats of all
descriptions. Ostrich plumes, of the
French variety, or uncurled, have re
placed the drooping willows. With

Very few flowers are used, though

Wool embroideries and wool ap

They are especially pretty on the deep

"William Morris is, of course, gener
ally recognized as the greatest prophet
of a day of growing grace in home
building, and adornment, and Ituukin,
with those of the elect who have re
ceived and understood his message, haa
foreshadowed a time when the aes
thetic should play a greater part in
our doily lives.
The arts and: craft movement to
America, and the new art movement
in Germany, both had the same end in
view a general improvement in pub
lic taste to a point where only well
designed houses, furniture, hangings
and rugs could be tolerated.
There Is a difference of opinion ns
to the American and German claims
of priority in this thought, but at any
rate, it is apparent that a relation
exists between the arte and crafts
movement here and the new art move
merit abroad.
It is Interesting to note how the
efforts of the craftsmen have affected
machine-made furniture, silver and
rugs, which now equal craftsmen's
work in all the essentials of tasteful
design and chaste simplicity, while
excelling It in general practical util
ity and reasonable price.
That a school of American archi
tecture and decorative art is now In
the process of formation is apparent
to anyone who studies the pretty cot
tages and bungalows erected within
the last ten or fifteen years, and the
rather low, wide-spreading type of
house, favored at present even by the
wealthy builder.
Period decoration has its friends and
prophets, of course, and many are its
undeniable charms and advantages;
yet to other students of home-making
the connection between a Francis I. or
Louis XIV. interior and an American
family, of Anglo-Saxon, Germanic or
Hibernian descent, is not readily appar
ent. Some architects, indeed, go so
far as to design houses to fit the
appearance and character of the occu
pants, even as one might thus design
wearing apparel, and, after all, though
a trifle extreme, the idea is far from
illogical.
Many of the older and well-defined
decorative periods, however, offer a
setting quite generally suitable to the
average American family. Sbereton,
Chippendale. Adams, Happelwhite and
William and Mary designs, in furni
ture, are of such a delightfully grace
ful and simple character as to be
almost universally acceptable. Colo
nial fashions, in architecture and fur
niture, are an adaptation of English
and French designs also widely appro
priate throughout the states descended
'from the colonies.
Often composite effects prove pleas
ing, a mingling of decorative elements
from different periods, if Judiciously
handled, possessing both harmony and
charm. Many decorators, in fact, advo
cate a not. too strict adherence to
period, claiming that to break up the
period a Kit relieves monotony.
Color Is an ever Important factor
in decoration and furnishing: for a
color scheme, well chosen, will render
attractive any but an exceptionally
unfortunate selection, or collection, of
household goods. Soft, neutrnl tones
for the large expanses, such as walls

in pottery, tapestry and pictures, is,
perhaps, the happiest and most reli
able arrangement.
Elaborate schemes involving daring,
rich or brilliant colors, should be en
trusted only to the expert by whose
skilled hands they may be safely ac
complished. A not too lively shade of autumnal
brown, for living room walls, is de
lightful with the many shades of oak
furniture, now so popular, such as
fumed oak, mission oak. weathered oak
or Flemish oak. Early English oak,
slightly lighter and richer In tone,
goes well with tapestry effects in
mingled green and brown, leaf designs
as a background in the wall covering.
With mahogany furniture, pale gray,
or gold, and white enamel, is very
pretty for walls and woodwork, while
Circassian walnut allows a back
ground of dull rose or bluish hue.
Dark oak is likewise handsome with
rather brilliant blue, even a delft being
permissible, though such strong colors
are not generally advisable.
In decorating and furnishing the home,
it is well to bear in mind the variety
of colors and costnme which season
and occasion may assemble within its
walls and to keep the broader tones
of living room and dining room, at
least, of so neutral a character as to
afford a charming background for any
well-chosen costume. Color and light
are the main elements in determining

In this day of broader culture and

in having at our command so many
sources of artistic delight from which
to draw. Pretty pieces of pottery,
' well designed, new embroideries, grace
ful baskets and art lamps offer innu
merable charming suggestions for

f the home.
I Pottery, indeed, even the most inex
pensive, may be highly artistic and
possessed of a great, decorative value.
The cultivation of a taste along this
line will enable one to select things
good in contour and color, even though
low In price. Some rather heavy Jap
ancEe pieces of dull, grayish stone
ware, with a merely indicated decora
.tlon of green branches and white flow
ers, were recently offered at prices

..were decidedly harmonious and taste
ful, satisfying even the most artistic
Japanese, and Chinese blue, in his

Among American potteries there are
many lovely pieces in dull, pale,
opaque glazed effects which, though
higher in price than Oriental wares,
are yet far from being unattainable

Brown baskets have recently sprung
into favor for decorative nses. As
center pieces upon tables, receptacles
for .bright colored fruit, or for ferns,
these rich, brown-toned wicker works ,
of woven willow or split bamboo are ,

tic Ideas In table decoration. Arti
ficial flowers nre also used to good
advantage in these baskets,, as are
autumn leaves, dried flowers, cat-tails
and prettily colored grasses. Arti
Gclal flowers are now recognized as
quite correct for home ndornmcnt, and,
Indeed, some of them nre so well done
as easily to pass for the real. Pre
served maiden, hair fern Is likewise so
natural in appearance that one can
scarcely tell it from the fresh grow
ing plant It has proven a boon to the
woman who never has any luck with
flowers and must constantly Eend her

Wicker and basket lamps are among
tho new things also, and shades of
bamboo or wicker, slllc-IIned, with
bases of pottery or bronze. Some very
pretty effects in willow lamps for
summer homes nre obtained by lining
the open-work shades with bright flow
ered cretonne. A lamp and shade of
this kind, in willow pointed green, had
a shade lining of very rich .red rose
and dark green leaved cretonne,
through which the light wrought beau
tiful effects.
Another idea is the matching of pat
tern upon the silk or cretonne shade
and pottery or porcelain lamp base.
In the decorators' window some very
pretty effects are displayed in ChlneEe
vases which have been fltted with elec
tric light fixture's, and shades of Chi
nese cretonne, or silk, matching the
pattertr of the vase.
Lamps have grown to be objects of
art almost within the last two decades,
with tho rather general adoption of
electric light. We have come suddenly
from a time when a really beautiful
lamp was a rarity to a day of bewild
ering variety and beauty in Illuml
narles. Side lighting fixtures nnd table
lamps are given preference today over
the central over-head fixtures, so long
regarded ns 'essential and inevitable.
This Is as it should be, for a light
more nearly on a level with the face
J is vastly more becoming than over
head illumination, -which throws gro-.
tcsquo dark shadows upon the face.
Side fixtures are likewise more artis
tic and more readily adaptable as mo
tives in the general scheme of decora
tion. . Lamps and lighting fixtures are very
carefully designed to blend harmoni
ously with interiors of every type and
period. Next to color, light is all im
portant In home decoration, and the
choice and placing of lights should
therefore be most carefully considered.

Tho custom of bringing to tabic tu
reens of soup and plalters of meat
seems to be falling into disuse in this
day and age. At many homes tables
nowadays the service is quite similar,
in this respect, to that, of a public eat

most, convenient and graceful for tho
formal diuncr5 there is something in
finitely more, homelike about service
at the hand of tho host, himself, from
capacious turocu or well-tilled platter.
This custom, happilj'. is not entirely ob
solete, it being adhered to by stmic of
the best, families.
jAmong the moro pleasing innovations
in table dressing is the fashion of
presenting each course in a service of
different design and coloring. This al
lows for a scries of artistic studies in
prett- china, tastefully arranged, and
is a relief from tho monotony of the
largo dinner set in ono design through
out. It may also prove a great cou

possible lo match tho pattern of her
china and keep a full set, in perfect
condition, by replacing breakages with
new pieces. It offers au opportunity to
utilize odd single course services, which
may have come into the housewife's
possession as gifts.
Good taste suggests a certain range
of color for the different services,
though, of courac, there is much lati
tude here for individual predilection.
As a rule, white and gold is tho best
choice for the service plate, as it har
monizes with plates in almost any
other color which may "be placed upon
it. Oyster plates, with a green deco
ration", arc perhaps preferable to all
others, as this color is in harmony
with the tones of the bivalve and sug
gests the sea. tiohl hands, or traceries,
ina3' relievo the- plain green and white
combination. Soups, which, lo bo cor
rect, should be in the new. small size,
aro also well chosen hi white and gold,
with permissible touches of red or
green. Tho small soup plate not ouly
possesses tho advantage of being much
daintier in suggestion than I he old
nine-inch variety, but also allows a
better appreciation of tho decorated
rim of tho service plate. Fish plates
may be in tho natural decoration of
live lish, with sparkling waves and
aquatic plants, or in simple conven
tionalized designs, in green and white,
or white and gold. The service of
gaino or cntrco may exhibit a decided
red in tho border, with strong touches
of gold and blaclc. , Tor tho body of
tho meal, simplo whito and gold usu
allv prevails, though very rich designs
in "which cobalt or torquise blue or
various shades of rose arc blended
with intricate gold traceries aro also
in favor. Palo yellow and soft green
arc tho preferred colors for the salad
service, though designs in dull Jap
anese reds and greens arc also appro
priate. ,
Afternoon tea service may be cither
of a quaint type, with decorations of
strong character, or in very dainty,
simple designs, the former being most
appropriate in the country, or iu sum
mer, upon the veranda or lawn.

fffir.ifiTff utIlltyt gbould quality be
borne in mind, for to nothing doe3
time apply a more severe test. This
Is wby, whenever possible, it Is best
to buy good Oriental rugs, which have
to recommend them not. only their sur
passing beauty and value as works of
art, but qualities of endurance as
well, far beyond those of almost any
other floor covering. Of course the
price exceeds that of other rugs, and
yet not so greatly as not to prove an
economy In the long run.
A' good rug should, aud will, with,
tho proper care, last nt least a life
time, even "under the hard conditions
of wear In this country. In the Orient,
where the custom of removing one's
street shoes, or sandals, upon entering
a bouse prevails, these rugs Inst for
generations, and improve in color and
Surface finish as they gather age.
The dyes, which Impart the beauti
ful hues to the yarn used in these
rugs, are all of a vegetable nature,
and the colors therefore tone perfectly
with the passage of time. Contact
with the heavy woolen stockings, worn
the year round by Oriental people,
causes the yarn of the nap of the rug
to unravel, and polishes the surface,
j
thus imparting a wonderful silken
sheen. So much admired by collectors
Is this velvety appearance that rug
dealers have resorted to various means
to produce this gloss artificially.
Dampening the surface with a solution
of glycerine, and pressing with very
hot irons, Imparts something the same
effect, but does not Improve the rug.
One should therefore favor a rug
which does not exhibit this character
istic too strongly, as, unless the price
be very high, one may be sure that
the gloss is not natural.
A still more damaging practice, re
sorted to both In the Orient and here.
Is the so-called washing process. New
rugs, in the vivid hues of freshly dyed
wools, are stretched on Inclined boards,
over which chlorine water Is permit
ted to flow. This fades the surfaces,
In soft tones, but so weakens the fibre
of the rag as to cut its lifetime In two.
A washed rug can easily be detected,
as upon examination It will be found
that only the surface of the nap is in
dull tones, very bright colors appear
back of the rug. Rugs which for any
Ing deeper in the fibre and upon the
reason have been exposed to sea water,
will fall to pieces quickly under every
day wear, as the chlorine from the
salt In the water rots the yarn.
Good rugs, especially Orientals,
should never be shaken or beaten, the
old-fashioned mauling with a stick,
cane or wire Implement being r;JrM
larly injurious. The carpet srB
and vacuum cleaner, for eTerrlB
and the steam or napthn process tJB
yonrly, will keep rugs nttf carpS
good condition and in FhattWiB
to the life of the fabric will mM
make up for the cosL in the (fclS
soiled rugs nre scrubbed wlthajIH
lather of pure Castile soap, raNwB
with the grain of the rug, JM
against it. They are rlnd 3B
slightly warm water, the eanpB
perature ns the first lather, mtB
water runs clear, then hung ijK
shady place to dry. t S

wrought Oriental pntterns areB
duplicated In machine-mnde do'csBj
velvets and brussels, affording raB
tasteful floor covering?. There
even those who prefer tho do-Hi
rug, ns it is more regulnr, mortjB
feet nnd lies flatter upon the fH

ed rugs, are also much favored bjR
orators. They equal the OrlentauB

largely for business Wear". ' It Will be
of. medium length- about .30. inches
moderately form-iitting, a vent in the'
centre seam, with regulation pockets,
with flaps to go in or out. This coat
has three buttons, and is cut at a slight
angle from the bottom button to the
bottom of the garment, with slightly
rounded corners. The sleeves will have
either real or simulated cuffs with
three buttons. The vest, of the same
material as the coat, will carry five
buttons, and will appear nearly an
Inch above the coat opening. The
morning coat, or cutaway, as it Is better
known, is popular with a certain ele
ment, especially among professional,
men who do not enre to wear the double-breasted
frock the "Prince Albert"
during business hours. This coat
will also be largely In evidence for
afternoon wear.
The former habit of appearing in
the afternoon, at any sort of function,
no matter how informal, in a Back or
lounge suit, has practically disap
peared. It was due partly to careless
ness and partly to want of knowl
edge as to the demands of propriety.
But the American public is now so
widely Informed ns to these things,
that the former" excuses no longer, ex
ist, and the custom is now a thing of
the past. Today, a man with social
pretensions, even of the humblest,
feels entirely out of place unless clad
in a cutaway, or frock in the social
centers of the country, and this is
especially true when he is in the com
pany of ladies. In other words, the
American now heeds the edicts of
fashion, and appears properly ac
coutored for business and social en
gagements. For town clothes, certainly the most
popular of all is the morning or cut
away coat The correct morning salt
L for the coming season will be a black
or dark gray coat, with waistcoat of
the same material, and gray trousers
with a narrow stripe. If the coat Is
of gray, the trousers should match. A
narrow strip of black braid, set in 14
of an inch from the edge of both coat
and waistcoat, forms an attractive and
pleasing novelty. The braid is also
set on the pocket flaps, the same dis
tance from the edge. The coat has a
welted breast pocket.
One of the things which makes the
morning coat 60 popular is the facfc
that it is better suited to the average
.

For semi-formal wear, the double

Men of middle age and past will wear

nation period this coat and the black

London than for several years before;
the mo6t prominent tailors of the
"WesiEnd, In the English metropolis,
predict that they will be fully as pop
ular, if not more so, from now until
next spring.
For the coming season the morn
ing or cutuway coat will be made to
roll, with three buttons, set In closely
together. The roll is quite soft to the
first button. Only the second button
of this coat Is designed to button,
The buttons are not silk-covered, but
are of bone, black of course. Some
of these coats will be shown, espe
cially among the custom trade, with
a double-breasted lapel with soft roll;
but this style will be the exception
and not the rule.

through, with worked button-holes.
This coat Is very walsty, or form
fitting, and is usually worn buttoned.
The tendency to button the waist
coat high has been somewhat modified
for the fall season. It musj, not be
cut too high nor too low, but nt a
happy medium, and must be in a direct
line with the roll of the coat. The
waistcoat opening is a moderate V in
shape. Five buttons are correct for
a coat cut not too long, and the last
button of the waistcoat should never
be buttoned. There Is positively' no
excuse for a chain hole.
Trousers will be a little more on
the order of the pegged top for tho
coming season. They should taper
nicely to the bottom, and care should
be taken to see that the back of the'
trousers come within an inch of thc
ground. They should not bag nor bulge
over thc front of the hoot, which
means that there should be a good
slope Ln the cut. Raised side searuB
of the wide type are fashionable.
There is a decided revival of the
demand for striped effects in the
darker shades for the coming season,
as these designs nre more adapted for
autumn and winter. These new effects
Hre heavier looking than the old style,
and, in many instances, there is a
very distant double Stripe which gives
the cloth a moat pronounced appear
ance. The popular shades will be
brown, green and gray.
Thc indications are that heavier
cloth will be quite fashionable for

H ers provided for the well-
dressed American such a
" ' remarkable variety of shirts,
neckties, and minor accessories to the
toilet as they have in store for the
fall and winter season of 1011-1012.
The soft shirt, in all sorts of nice
fabrics, continues to hold the market,
in exclusive and, ordinary wear alike.
But the much-vaunted soft collar has
failed, to meet the expectations of Its
; progenltdrs. During the past summer
It was worn very little by men of
taste; for Its appearance Is untidy and
i it proved no more comfortable than
the usual starched linen collar. For
the fall and winter It is not In evl-
dence at all, and probably will not be
revived next spring.
Practically all shirts carry .the
French cuffs that Is, the uris'tarehed,
I turned-back kind. These are worn
almost universally at all times except
for more or less formal functions that
call for starched white linen. They
may be obtained at all prices, from
$1.50 up. Light-weight French batiste
shfrts average $5.50, so do silk negli
gees, custom made. These, and the
less expensive grades, made from linen,
muslin, and other fabrics, including
percales, madras and surah silks, are
worn to business by young and old.
by men of moderate Income and those
who can afford to gratify expensive
tastes. 1
A swell shirting, which will be made
up for the fall and winter in both
negligee and pleated, is the Russian
cord. This Is found mostly in laven
der, blue and tan, and will undoubt-l
cdly be 'extremely popular among the
hlgh-clas3 trade. Pique and mercer
ized detachable collars are on sale, but1
haberdashers do not predict any exten
sive demand for them.
Neckwear Is shown in an astonish
ing variety of weaves and patterns,
both in four-in-hands and "bat wing"
ties. The latter arc In great favor
for early fall, and may be had in
accordeon weaves, solid colors, stripes,
diagonals and "polka dots."
The latter pattern has come into
style again, and will bo worn exten
sively during the coming season, espe
cially Iru four-in-hands. So far, the
dots are confined to white against dark
blue or some other solid color; they
vary in size from a quarter to half
an inch In diameter.
The newest thing in neckwear, de
signed, especially for the fall trade, is
known as the handkerchief scarf. This
is a four-in-hand, of generous size;
most of them are exceedingly gaudy,
carrying brilliant combinations of col
ors in what is designated ns Persian
designs. "It is astonishing," said ' a
prominent haberdasher, "to see how
men's tastes change; this is no longer
a feminine prerogative. Thousands of
men are wearing today the brightest
combinations of color imaginable men
who a short while ago would not have
thought of wearing anything but black,
white, gray, or the soberest combina
tions." But the preference for the quieter
combinations still exerts an influence,
and for the fall, besides the brilliant
Persian designs inrumchundas and fou
lards, are many plain colors and com
binations with neat, attractive effects
in stripes nnd diagonals. In fact, I
have been informed that fully 60 per
cent of the neckties sold of late have
been in solid colors or in "self stripes
that is, stripes of the same color,
but different shade, as the body of
the tie.
In the more exclusive trade exclu
sive, in this connection, usually means
nothing more than expensive some
houses show a striking novelty in a
four-in-hand of bright scarlet, made
of Irish muslin, which sells for $1.50.
Netted neckwear is practically de Sv.(
A new design, created especially fori
autumn, is of alternating stripes of
gray and green, each stripe being
inch wide, and composed of countless j
smaller stripes In the weave. This isj
a- decided novelty, and extremely at-j
tractive to the eye. j
Fancy waistcoats are to be had prac-j
tically without restriction as to style,
or pattern. Perhaps the most popu-'
lar, and certainly one of the nicest in
appearance, is made of silk or velvet
with perpendicular stripes, less than
a quarter of an inch wide, of black
and silver gray. For autumn wear are
Borne of white vyelle flannel, with nar
row stripe's of blue or black. The Tux
edo and dress vest is of white French
pique; with the dinner coat simple
effects In gray and In black-and-white
may be worn.
In underwear, union suits vie with
two-piece suits in about equal ratio;
in the former, the suit with half arms
and ankle-length drawers, which costs
from .$1.50 up, seems to be in great
favor. These come in crepe, solsette
and heavier fabrics".
Hardly any socks are to be seen
except silk and silk-and-lisle. It is
actually true that real silk socks have
been sold for 25 cents a pair; the
average price for the fall trade Is 35
cents, or three pairs for a dollar. Cot
ton and woolen socks are shown only
when called for. They are all in solid
colors, no stripes or other combinations
being on view.
Jewelry for men's wear, for formal
dress or otherwise, is measured only
by the contents of the buyer's purse.
Almost everything is "matched" nowa
days comes In "sets," including shirt
studs, vest buttons, cuff links, and,
when the studs are not worn, stickpin
as well. These sets may be bought
expensively or otherwise. The latest
offering for fall has a tiny bit of plati
num in the centre of a button of
mother -of -pearl. Cat's -eyes, moon-

By Associated Pre3B.
. NEW.-. YORK, r Sept. .16. The Morrls
Flynn? fight in. Madison Square. Garden
last night, which: resulted in defeat for
tho Oklahoma "white hope," proves to
have been ,a disastrous venture for the
New York promoters, aqcording to ' the
figures published here today.
Tho high prices charged for seats 52
to $20 kept the crowd down to about
3000 persons, and most of these were in
the cheaper sections. Boxing fans esti
mated tho gate receipts at $15,000. Out
of tliat -total -tho- promoters arc under
contract to. give Morrl3 $10,000 and Flynn
57000, leaving tho ..club apparently with
a deficit ol $2000 aside from the' expense
of staging .the bout. ;
Police - reports show that tho" fight
crowd, " thoilgh smaller than expected,,
was -a. harvest for pickpockets. At least
51000 was stolen ' and as much more in
Jewelry. A -number of men arrested in
the fight crowd were hold' at the -various
police stations 'and-the police " expect tQ
arrest more. today. Tt Is declared .that
at least 300 fight fans were robbed dur
ing the evening.
An unusual Incident in connection with
tho battlo was the. presence In a box of
three young women. They were dressed,
in mcn'B clothes and tho disguise de
ceived the- gatekeepers and a few of tho
spectators. Onco In their seats they
betrayed themselves. Their presence cre
ated no flutter In the crowd, which was
Intent on the programme, and nobody re
quested them to leave". Once tho bout
began they wero " as little noticed as
though they had been lay figures in front
of a clothing store. All three smoked
, cigarettes constantly throughout tho
evening.
Fight fans agreed today that the defeat
of Morris was the most complete over
seen hero. No pugilist of modern times
ever took such a hammering as did Mor
ris. He wns unable to block or side
stop Flynn's wallops, and the only pro
tection ho could provide for himself was
by throwing his weight upon .Ids. oppo
nent when .ho clinched. -He. bled profuse
ly and was in such distress in the last
few. rounds that ringside spectators'
begged him to ault, but the big engineer
did not know the meaning of that word.
Flynn escaped without any serious
bruises.

, Manager ..Downing of tho Manhattan

tiously for this -contest and will have no

met'Jlmmlo Reagan and realizes that a

Davis has many friends who think he

ily for the past two year3 and it remains

Jack Downey and Patsy McKenna. who

both lh good condition, to so the ,sx
rounds at top speed and as they are
both willing mLxers should prove a very
interesting contest.

been .training for the four-round prelim
inary with 4o Pcadbn and may decide

doors open at 7 o'clock Monday night.

In -the. meantime tho .effect of anti

thoroughbreds is thus set forth in an

assistant secretary of the Jockey club,
and an authority on the subject:
"Thnl something like a deathblow
has been struck at the high-spirited
thoroughbred horse in America cannot
be doubted when we look at tho facts,''
says Mr. Daiugoriield. "The great pe
cuniary loss to America is not the
only one. to be considered. Neither is
the sentimental one. But tho danger to
the future character of tho Amorican
horse is a serious menace. The num
ber of thoroughbred horseB bred in
this couutr has decreased from an
average of 4,700 a few years ago to n
bare thousand and less this year. This
last figure will be still further de
creased in another yerfr, and each and
every year fewer arid fewer 'fine horses
will appear,
" The newspapers are constantly ro
ceiving letters asking why there cau't
be racing for the fun of It without
bookmuking. Thero could if the public
would patronize the races sufficiently
to make it worth while, but it. won 't.
There could if there was some way ol
fixing the standard of a thoroughbred
horse other than the supreme standard
of the race track. But there isn't
Wealthy owners are not goinc to breed
fino liornos-with no opportunity of dis
tinguishing between the hoT.se thai
has speed and the horse that has not
Tn all tho centuries that the thorough
bred has been, supremo in tho horse
world tho race irack has been the final
test of a horse's worth, and thero is
no other test possible.
Bacing Only Beal Test.
"With possibly one exception there
has never boen a sire who begot off
spring worth $500 that was not him
self a racer. Without bookmaking or
some equivalent the public will not at
tend sufficiontlv to make tho , receipts
great enough to pay good ' purses,

stant infusion of thoroughbred stock,

"Thoroughbred horses, tracing their

B. ITaggin, for instance, has just im
ported six Shire stallions from Belgium
and other foreign countries. They
weigh 1,800 pounds or more, and he
will, breed them to thoroughbred marcs
weighing J, 000 pounds. Tn this way
he expeats to get horses nimble enough
to take the places of the. mules of
Kentucky, who do wonderful work in
the muddy and uneven farms of that
slate.
"Tliloss to America from Ujo ex
porting of horses and the through de
parting to other shores of big stables
and of -wealthy horsemen is another side
of tho question that is appalling. Just
to mention a few is startling.
'William Astor Ch'Riiler has sent his
entire breeding stud from his Virginia

est and lorgesfc breeders in the coun

"T think that the noxt man to flag",
gin whose establishment has been re
duced the most is James R. Keene. he
having shipped 150 Etnllions and two
year-olds to tho Argentine, and his
entire crop of two-year-olds and racing
stable pf 1W1 to England. TI. B. Duv
yea has entirely deserted America as
a racing country with a very large rac
ing stable and Htud.
j "Harry Payne Whitney with his en
tire racing stable, American trainor
and nil stable help, has gone to Eng
land. Mr. Whitney has this yoar pur
chased the entire crop or "yearlings
from the Ca6tleton stud, .James B.
Keene 's great Kentucky breeding place.
And all these horses and all the re
mainder of his own stable will bo
shipped to Encland within the next
thirty Hays. The magnitude of Mr.
Whitney .'s English racing ventures niay
be imagined from his havinjr more than

and Derby.
Spend Millions Abroad.
. "Clarence IT. Mnckay has shipped
his whole stud, headed by the famous
race horse Meddler, and ho and Mr.

sively abroad.
"John E. Mnddon has very much re
duced his enormous breeding and racing
establishment bv sales of Louis Wp
nans nnd haB- shipped a large consign
ment of brood mares to Eugene Leigh,
another American in France,

PACKARD FACTORY
HAS BIG PAYROLL
Within a period of ten-minutes' Satur
day, September 0. the Packard Motor
Car company disbursed in wages S2S3.
:ill. covering tho labor account for one
half month at Its factory in Detroit. The
payroll for August amounts to $ii24.
40j the largest sum ever paid out In
wages for a single month by any manu
facturing enterprise In Michigan. This Is
also the record payroll for any automo
bile factory In the world.
There arc now 7675 employees in the
Packard shops. Shortly before the clos
ing hour on payday twenty division pay
masters, each nccompanbid by two armed
guards, scatter through tho plant and
take positions at as many different sta
tions. The men form In lines and nn
proach these stations ns they leavq the
shops. The man nt the head of the line
hands In his paycheck to a representa
tive of tho time office, who calls off
the number. A man from tho account
ing deportment passes out. the envelope
and they are ready for tho next trans
action. II. takes only about a second for
each man and In a remarkably short
. spaco of time the line mcltr, away.
The rate of wanes, if maintained for
a year, will meon nn annual payroll In
excess of 5G.000.000. Tn round numbers,
the money nald out for raw materials
entering Into Packard cars in a yoar
amounts to the same sum.
The company Is now -working a lar--'
night force and five buildings are under
construction to provide additions to the
present floor space of thlrtv-thrce acres.
On August 31 tho company .shipped
forty-ono possencer cars, of which twenty
were "Sixes."' Twelve trucks left the fac
tory the same, day, establishing a new
high record for oho day's business for
this concern. Although three machines
were shipped by boat and two wero de
llvorcd at tho factory, twenty-seven
freight cars were required to handle the
day's shipments by rail.

IB EXONERATED
B RACESJEWARDS
Charges Against American
Jockey Declared to Be With
out Any Foundation.
BY RICHARD DAHLGEEN.
Special Cable to The Tribune.
' LONDON. Sept. 16. There Is a very
general satisfaction among racing men
that the Jockey club has entirely exon
erated Danny Mahcr. the great American
Jockey, from the. charge that he had not
properly ridden Sallust at tho Leicester
meeting.
Mahcr has gained a place for himself
second to no Jockey in the history of the
British turf. Ills 7nodesty and all-around
cleverness has made him very popular,
and tlje charge that ho had ridden a
suspicious raco came as a complete
shock. His exoneration is generally com
mended. In writing of the affair ''Spear
mint," one of tho leading sporting writers
In England.- says:
"In ono way the suspension of Danny
Mahcr by the Leicester executive and his
subsequent vindication by the stewards of
the Jockey club has served a moBt use
ful purpose. Jt has completely and ef
fectually silenced the tongues of the
scandal-mongers. Tn tho domain of
racing, as everywhere else In this funny
old world, thcro abound persons of such
strange mental constitution that they
must forever be. thinking evil of their
fellow beings. It Is scarcely credible, but
It Is nevertheless true that, because Ma
her has had a long run of bad luck, many
pooplo havo concluded that to put It
mildly he has not boon doing his best.
Since the Leicester Incident f have had
scores of letters on the. subject of Ma
her's riding, and, having destroyed thorn
all as soon as read, I cannot recall th-at

American Jockey, The foundations of

Maher Is VIndicatod.
"To my way of thinking. Maher has
been olie of tho greatest benefactors that
the British turf has ever' had. Not onlv
has he adorned and embellished it by his
genius aF a horseman, but by his mod
est, unassuming conduct he has earned
the .respect and admiration cf every man
of standing and influence connected with
tho sport. ThOHe who suggest that
Mahcr Is not ridng as he ought to do
belong to that vpnomoualy ignorant class
which is fprever seoking for sinister mo
tives where none are to be found. Mahcr
has hecii vindicated by the highest tri
bunal of 'Justice known to tho snort.
Why. then, 'should the groundlings con
tinue to snarl and grumble? Watch how
they will change their tune If Maher
should haopen suddenly upon a streak
of luck. To the little American I offer
my heartiest congratulations on having
emerged hf triumphantly from such a
trying ordeal. He was at most tho vic
tim of a regrettable misunderstanding.
"It Is a. nity that the artlHtry of Maher
Is not more common among one jockevn
I recently referred to a case of the
butcher-boy tyne of riding which or
currod at one of our south coast meet
ings. Sipce then I have learned from a
trainer friend that tho animal conocrncu
a most valuable and promising one
was so badly cut about the head and
face, especially near the oyrs, that it
was at one time thought that It had
beon permanently damaged. Since Its
return to Its training auarters It ha
been ho nervous and out of sorts that it
has had to have veterinary treatment.
Surely this is the sort of riding thn
stewards could deteet nnd ounish with
out any difficulty. 1 am quite convinced
that, much valuable blood stock is
ruined each year by the stunldly crul

Let them be Tratched and their Daeslon
for excessive Diinlshment rigorously sup
pressed." Joluison Fight Probably Off,

Lord Marcus Beresford, who lias su
preme management of King Goorge's
stud, is like all the Waterford family,
full of high spirits. There is hut one per
son entitled to .drive down Rotten Row,
tho duke of St. Albans, and it is doubt
ful if ever he cares to exorcise the privi
lege. "But Lord Marcus bet ho would do
It in broad . daylight and without inter
ference. The wager was accented and
(he time fixed for the adventure about
noon All Lord Marcus's friends cam
trooping along to see him. but time went
on, and nothing could be seen of tho
sportsman. By and by a watering cart
came along-, driven by the usual water
man in a smock. As the car passed,
along leisurely the driver smiled, arid on
closer observation Lord Marcus's friends
recognized the winner of, the wager. A
courtier and a sportsman, ho has a host
of friends. Like her husband, Lady Mar
cus, who was Miss Ridley, is fond of
horses and racing, and is seen at all the
smart race meetings.
There is no truth In the announcement
which has bepn sent all round the press,
that the king has ordered a new racing
yacht to be built for him, which Is" to
be completed and ready for sea in the
spring. It would really be interesting to
learn how' all these fictions originate. The
kljig has no Intention of either building
or buying another yacht, and thcro Is no'
prospect of his taking "an active part in
yacht racing.' It was only the other
day that it was stated that the king had
"made over" King Edward's racing cut
ter Britannia to tho prince of Wales. His
majesty's participation, in yacht racing
will be limited to the Cowes regatta i
week.
Few Distance Horses.
English turf authorities are trying to
find a reason for the acknowledged scar
city of staying or distance performers on
the British training grounds, "Augur."
in the Sporttng Life, says: "The truth
of the matter would seem to bp. that
practically all the interest onco taken in
long-distance racing Is now non-existent,
or, at any rato, rapidly Is becoming
so. Nowadays everything Is sacrificed to
speed. Personally 1 think the stamina
of our thoroughbreds has deteriorated of
late years, and this opinion Is unreserv
edly shared by more than one "veteran
racegoer whom I have consulted."
i He regretfully comments on tho decline
of tho Chester cup. and tho Northumber
land plate, the Godwood plate, and every
other long-distance handicap excepting
the Cosarcwltch. and adds:
"The present state of affairs could be
readily bettered, but the methods I
recommend are. I fear, far too drastic
to possess any chanco of over getting
beyond the stage of discussion". I would
absolutely abolish all two-year-old rac-'
Ing except In September. Odlober and
November; do away with selling plates
of whatever kind or description; make
the nilnnium distance of every race a
nillo, except in the caso of two-year-bids,
and insist that every programme
should Include at least two races per day
of two miles or over. There Is nothing
particularly original about these sugges
tions, for they obtain in France to a
modified degree.
In that country there are no two-year-old
races until August, and horses three
years old and over rarely run less than
a mile. A typical day's racing at
Chantilly on a Sunday in May was one
to five events, the distances of which
wero one mile and lhrtp. furlongs, two
miles and a half, one ,mllc and a quar
ter, one mile and a half and one mile
and a quarter.
"U" FOOTBALL TEAM
IS STRENGTHENED
Coach Bennion's football squad, which
has been practicing for the last two
weeks, had Its last workout yesterday
prior to the opening of the school work.
The squad has beep small up to tho
present time, but with the close of regis
tration more of the fe!low3 arc expected
to show up.
Last night three of the men on whom
Bennion places a lot of hope were seen In
harness on Cummlugs field. They were
Gordon Klrby. Deane and Peterson.
Gordon Klrby played for three years on
the Salt Lako high school team and then
one year as tackle on the freshman team.
He Is both big and fast, and will be a
valuable addition to the squad. He was
one of the best sprinters on the uni
versity track team last spring and be
should be exceptionally fast this season.
Peterson started to play one of tho end
positions last fall In the game with the
Colorado Miners and was playing -a star
game, when he was injured and had to
retire for the remainder of the season.
Ho has thoroughly recovered, however,
and will be In the practices from now on-
Deano was on the "U" squad last
year, acting In tho capacity of utility
map. He played end in (Some of the
games and proved himself a strong man
on defense. Ashton and Sutherland, twoi
of the most promising graduates of the
1910 freshman team, registered yester
day and after Monday will be seen regu
larly at t lie afternoon practices.

Arundel Smith, pretty and "deucedly English, ,

He soon met his heart's desire in the person of an

NOT all the members of the divorce colouy are from
the "400" or the stage. Moro thau'half prob
ably are working their way. They come from the mass
of American people aud enter at once into the business
life of the towu. Stenographers, dressmakers, laun
dresses, telepbono operators, waitresses, manicurists
and hairdrcssere, any trade or profession you may think
of, they are all thero for the same purpose. Jt. is -a
never ending procession. They come and go, followed
by another consignment to fill in the vacant places.
Jt is not an unusual thing for a member of the colouy
to enter a. shop and ask for her favorite sales-lady,
only to find her gone, Jf she asks what has become
of her, the answer is always the same.
"Wiry, don't you know? She got hers last Wednes
day, and she declared sho y couldu 't stay another
minute. I thought you knew that her time was about
.up,"
The men are a little more stealthy in their comings
and goings than tbo women. They sneak into town
overnight, buy up a business from some departing
brother, change the name on the window and start in
where bo left off. Probably your favorite cigar store
is owned by a candidate) for divorce, who hires similar
liberty seekers as his clerks. Lawyers who have beeu
prominent in the East rent, offices on a eix-monih
lease, hang out their shingles, and represent a hundred
anxious clients before their owu cases are called. You'
just get accustomed to your waiter at the hotel when
he "gets his" and leaves for parts unknown.
"With the men employment is au Import ant factor
.in establishing a residence, and their frantic searches
for something that can be called employment furnish
great amusement for tho colony. Chauffeurs and waiters
have an easy timo finding something to do, for they
arc greatly in demand, but hundreds are obliged- to
take what they can got. Tho wealthy president of an
Eastern bank worked as a chauffeur during his entire
stay. Up. was known to his employers as "George."
A druggist from Illinois became a bartender iu one of
the best appointed saloons in the main street. A. silver
tongued minister of the "gospel went to work in the
freight yards of the Southern Pacific. Railroad. The
clerk who sells you your socks may be a millionaire
in disguise, and the delivery boy of your favorite gro
cery may be a doctor or an architect.
AS a rule the floating citizens of Reno are very se
cretive and questions are" not popular. Inquis
itive peoplo are snubbed as uot fit, persons to move
in the best society. Many of the colonists do not want
.the outside world to know where they are. Asa proof
of this one has only to see the nighty parade to the
Southern Pacific station. Every evening there is a
steady procession of divorce candidates on its way to
the railroad mailbox. A railway postmark tolls no
tales, and in this way the recipients of the epistles may
be left, completely in tho dark as to one's whereabouts.
This custom is known among the colonists as "The
Convict's Resort," and knowing smiles are exchanged
when two conspirators meet at the mail box.
Ijast year when the census man arrived in Reno
pandemonium reigned for several days. lie was about
as welcome a visitor to the seekers of freedom as a
red rag to a herd of gentlemen kine. They considered
him altogether too inquisitive, and they cast about
them for some 'way iu which to evade him. The only
persons who held 'authoritative positions iu the town
with whom they wore intimately acquainted were the
judges who tried the divorce cases. So tho fair un
knowns called upon Judges Orr and Pike.
They wanted to know if the good, kind judges
couldn't tell them some way to escape from the awful
census enumerator, .but the Itiud judges frankly told
them that it was dangerous to trifle with the agents
of Uncle Samuel and that tho best course was to stand
right up and be counted. It. had another advantage
also, as it established residence of tho prospective lit
igant beyond the shadow of doubt, and this ia a valu
able assot when one goes divorcing.
But in spito of the ndvice of the judges, the census
man did not havo easy sailing. When ho swooped down
on the .Colonial and Stewart apartmont houses he found
t.hnt a gicat many of tho occupants were away on trips.
Coachrrfeu and maids had suddenly become deaf aud
dumb. Butlers and grocers, much to their own regret,
had never .learned the English laugunge. Even tho
very dogs in tho streots were muzzled. Tho census
man was clearh' in a pdedicament. IIo wns persist
ent, however, and somotimes he caught his prey napping
and gained admittance.
At such times ho would begin with tho usual ques
tions about the name, age, color nnd ancostrnl history
of the residents. Then he would move on to tho di
vorce queries, and that's whore tho ombarrassing fea
ture came in. It is a bother to have to tell in detail
about ono's previous husbands and wives, cspecially
when one may not hayo kept a notebook. JIow could
a woman .bo expected :to know the full name of her
second or third husband when she was about to shed
her tenth 1
Despite the difficulties, however, the census man
succeeded in rounding up more than two hundred di
vorced folks and put- their life stories down on. the
blanks.
nn HERE havo been many now romances born from
the ashe3 of tho old ones at Reno. The Httlo
city has acted as a sort of clearing house for the ro
mating of the misfits. Their parties in the homes, the
dances at the roadhouscs and the late parlies at the
cafes have been responsible for awakening in the heart
of many a man and woman a fire which thej had long
thought extinguished. In spite of former protestations
to' the contrary, they find themselves willing to try
again, hoping that this time it will "take."
Alice Johnson of New York met also- divorced
Attorney-General Stoddard of Nevada at an cveningj
gathering at Reno, and considered him interesting
enough to marry, so they wcut to the judge who had
given each of them their decrees and became one
again. Mrs. Freida Thaw Pctt, who had already made'
two unsuccessful attempts to get a husband whom she
could put up with and who would stick, fell in love
with a young mining engineer who attended some of
her entertainments, with the result that she is now
Mrs. Young and lives 4." a mining camp far away among
tho mountains, and it is said that at' last she is
happy. Mrs. Henry Spies Kip also chose the simple
life for her last experiment. She has married a young
mining superintendent and gone to live among the
'snowy peaks of California. Tt. seems almost a repiti
tion of tlio tales of Bret llartc.
There is tragedy, too, in tho chaos of Reno's
daily life. Many tender hearts are broken iu the very
operation of mending others. There are plenty of hus
bands and wives who really love and who Teali.c that
the differences between them and their spouses have
been brought, about .by simple misunderstandings that
could b-reasily cleared up if the other would only listen
to renson, but in the heat of tho moment he or she
has fled to Reno and that inexorable mill has ground
out a decree of divorce before a settlement could bo
made.
npHEN, too, the most of the beauties who seek frcc-
dom are pledged to another beforo they arrive
in the Sagebrush State. They amuse themselves with
the youth of the town until the day comes when thc3'
have received tho little decree they have been waitiug
for so patiently Then they celebrate. The3' givo a
wonderful dinner. The fair one is congratulated on '
her coming marriage, which up to this time has not
been mentioned aloud (it, isn't considered good form
to do so), and joy reigns supreme.. But there is one
sad heart among them, The bo' who has danced at
tendance upon her during tho long wait does not. fcol
happ3'. He creeps home a little more cynical than ho
wns beforo and considerably poorer. The society of
these beautiful and witty women has completely spoiled '
him for the simple village maiden whom he formerly
adorqd. And yet he is not for them.
The lure of Reno 1ms boon felt throughout tho
world, and each day brings some one who wishes to
rid himself of an impediment which ho acquired in
years gone by. Special trains are organized from time
to time to carry matrimonial misfits to their haven of
rest. It. is not so uncommon to find that ever' occupant
of n particular Pullman car on tho Overland Limit od
is bound for the divorce mill at Reno, Tho town has
been well recommended by those who havo gninod
